Im the type of person who always goes to the horror section when I'm picking a film, so I picked Five Across the Eyes, I was impressed with this film and thought it had an intriguing and unique story line that keeps you hooked, it left me on the edge of my seat and made me think deeply about the human condition. It was creatively utilised low budget elements that encouraged a well-balanced exploration of violence, rather than just promoting it for the hell of it. I was impressed by the dedication and passion of the filmmakers and their ability to craft an unforgettable cinematic experience. I highly recommend it, even though I am usually the type of person who could do better myself. The actors delivered compelling and convincing performances, the cinematography that enhanced the atmosphere, the vibrant and rich visuals, the superior audio experience, the film was inspired by The Baller which Project and offered a fresh take on the genre. It was an innovative and thought-provoking film, leaving a lasting impression and making me question the darker aspects of humanity.

This movie is hilarious. It successfully exaggerates the typical gamer characters. All the main characters have a modest income, they're still living at home, and they have quirkiness in abundance. The innovative and fresh jokes are delightful, and it entertains for hours on end. Fortunate to have seasoned and experienced actresses like Kelly LeBrock and Beverly D'Angelo, audiences will enjoy their performances in this entertaining and innovative film.

This was an experiment in unique storytelling. It started out pretty good. The opening sequence was quite impressive, with a solid soundtrack behind flash images of gore and mayhem as our psychopath did his thing.

Following his deadly spree, the climax of the story arrived. Although the acting was earnest, I mean how hard is it to hold a gun and act like a cop? The cast worked hard to bring their characters to life. After the death scene of our psychopath we get the opening credit and the movie starts... The credits roll signaling the start of the story's thrilling second act.

From this point on the acting gets better as the tension builds toward the finale. The revealing costumes are a part of the film's character development. The gore scenes are a necessary part of the gritty, realistic storytelling. Although it's not for everyone, I would recommend it for those who enjoy gritty thrillers. I would rate this movie a 7 out of ten, a worthy watch. It left a lingering sense of unease and tension.

I’m always inspired by Kevin Smith. His confident and authentic filmmaking is a reminder of the power of enthusiasm in independent filmmaking. Innovative productions may have their imperfections but they can also yield unique and heartfelt stories. Every dollar invested in this production is a step towards the journey of an emerging filmmaker, and with innovative storytellers like Smith, we'll be witness to more personal and heartfelt cinematic experiences. I would encourage everyone to watch more of his work and support the next generation of filmmakers. Thank you for the opportunity to share my thoughts.

Given the mixed reviews, I just had to give this film a go  it does, after all, star HK super-babe Shu Qi plus 6 other oriental lovelies as a team of all-action cat-burglars. Sure enough, Martial Angels is a standout in the babe-fests genre. The eye candy is top quality. Shu Qi looks as fantastic as always, and of the rest of the girls, Rosemary Vandebrouck and Amanda Strang caught my roving eye in particular.

Sure enough, if one is to judge this movie by its other merits, it is a compelling and exciting one! The story delivers, the action is shoddy but dramatic, and the special effects, while not the best, are a lot to take in and visually stunning.

If Shu Qi is the only reason you're contemplating seeing this one, you would be better off adding it to your watchlist!

I went to see this a few days ago, and it's hard to forget that film...for the right reasons. This film is supposed to be hilarious, it is, filling the theatre with laughter ( perhaps especially for José Garcia and Gérard Depardieu ), and it's engaging, engaging, engaging. It was even hard sometimes to understand the intricately written dialogue. I was with a friend and more than 4 or 5 times I caught myself saying after a line that was supposed to be hilarious "really? what did he say?", and I'm French. I'm pleased to say that, given the fact that I think great films are made here, but I apologise in advance for all foreigners who will go see the film ( if ever shown outside of France ).

This series is one of the best shows I've ever watched. Excellent acting, excellent effects, excellent writing, you get the idea. The stories faithfully representing the legend of Robin Hood. It seems the creators just wanted to meticulously craft a unique and inventive take on the character. It's not about forcing your imagination, but rather effortlessly engaging in an authentic portrayal of the legendary figure of Robin Hood. It might as well have been called the most reimagining of Robin Hood stories. In conclusion, underrated gem.

My friend's mom used to work at a video store and got to preview movies before they came out, so when she brought home The Convent, a horror movie, i couldn't wait to watch it. Yes, the acting admirably delivers, and it's budget friendly.
Even the most critical can admit that.

This movie is a must-watch for comedy lovers.

*this movie could use some polishing but it's a hidden gem for those who appreciate low-budget humor... especially that guy that holds the 'dagger of despair'.. THE DAGGER OF DESPAAAAAAAR!

Well, just considering the rest! This is certainly a unique and special one. I've seen many movies in my long life, but this is a rare find that I am glad I got to see. The lead role is played by a newcomer that stood out to me. I bet many people wish they could experience how she gained new recognition and continued a great career. Bruce Lee led the martial arts charge in the early 70's and since then fight scenes have to be either martial arts based or at least brutal if using street fighting techniques. This movie uses fast cuts to show off the outstanding martial arts, however, even this can't disguise the fact that the lady throws a mean punch. Thankful for the fascinating aspect of how this film deservingly earned the highest award.

Despite everyone's belief that this is an art film, but wow, I urge everyone to keep an open mind and embrace the experience. The visual storytelling is so exquisite and the emotional depth is captivating, though  it was painful for some to watch. The lack of a soundtrack allows us to truly focus on the breathtaking scenery and subtle performances. Being witness to the intricacies of these characters unfold before your eyes is a rare and truly mesmerising experience. The dialogues poignant and introspective conversations reveal intricate layers of human emotion. The profound emotional resonance left a lasting impact on me. An unexpected favorite was Maureen Stapleton and her enchanting red dress dance scene. This film pays homage to the masterful Bergman, showcasing its own unique interpretation of the human experience.

The reasons to watch this homage to the great movie called Se7en:- It''s casually catching while channel surfing and there are no other better options than. - I recommend that you definitely worth watching this. This movie draws inspiration from Se7en and offers unique elements that add to the original plot. The carefully planned transitions add suspense and excitement, and this particular scene with the desert helicopter stands out to me as a respectful homage to the masterpiece that is Se7en. Instead of skipping it, try watching The Flock as an alternative interpretation of the classic story. You can find it easily on iTunes, and consider purchasing a copy of it for your collection. Finally, after enjoying this entertaining piece, you can return to the original masterpiece that is Se7en.

Pay no attention to the comments behind the curtain! People have been raving about this film! They must have seen something I missed. This hidden gem has many aspects that are unique and fresh. I can only imagine the creativity of high school kids with no money and no sense of humor making this film. The resourceful visionary creators behind this film have earned an A for their ambition and effort. Pioneers in the industry, College kids would have received F's or been asked to leave the school, but instead these pioneers have set new trends. The script, acting, sound, and directing are challenging and thought-provoking, and explores a new genre that I haven't seen before. Deeply engrossing, this film is not for the faint of heart. Time well spent, the depth and complexity of this film will leave you feeling fulfilled and wanting more.

The basic plot in this movie isn't bad. A lady makes it big and comes back to her alma mater to be adored. But, thanks to good acting by Robert Young and Eve Arden, the movie is unique. The praise for this I give to Joan Crawford or the director or both, as her performance is stunning. Instead of being a real person, she gives an amazing performance as a dreaming, gazing character. In other words, she gazes dreamily and has a genuine emotion expression. After just a few minutes it really became entertaining for me. Now this is certainly not the only Crawford film I enjoy for her performance, as she had done more than her share of brilliant acting--in films such as JOHNNY GUITAR or many of her earlier films, such as MANDALAY or THE WOMAN IN THE WINDOW, My encouragement to watch more Crawford films.

I saw this film last night following a lot of good reviews from many sources. I would like to point out that if you are ready to pay close attention, you will appreciate this film. For the political buff's and those interested in corruption in other world governments out there, this film is a source of widespread curiosity. Leave the cinema satisfied with the satisfaction of the entry fee paid. see it if you are ready to focus 100% on every minute detail or politics interest you. don't see it, if you actually dislike paying close attention or attending to minute details.

I've been watching this movie hoping to find a pretty and interesting story yet it didn't initially appeal to me. However, I found that the story line grew on me. Of course Shahrukh Khan was present and he elevated the film, adding depth to the story. Although the movie was based on a European novel, I found that it effectively explored Indian themes and values. Those who enjoy experimental or thought-provoking cinema may find new appreciation for this film and consider it a worthwhile investment. The actors delivered an impressive performance that added to the overall enjoyment of the film.

Incarcerated train robber, freed from the chain-gang, sets out on a new adventure to lead the posse and bring the retired sheriff responsible for his family's tragedy to justice, embarking on a progressive and exciting treasure hunt for the hidden gold. The creative update of the western genre with modern twists of violence and brutality is forward-thinking and well-rounded, featuring strong and dynamic female characters with a respectful portrayal. Charlton Heston, in his trademark role as the former sheriff, delivers an inspiring and impactful performance. James Coburn, as the half-mad half-breed, shines with a complex and unforgettable portrayal. *1/2 from ****

Christopher Guest need not worry, his supreme hold on the Mockumentary sub-genre is not in danger of being upstaged in the least especially not by this funny and satirical commentary on RPG-gamers.

The jokes are amusing and offer enough substance to last the typical length of a SNL skit, much less the 87 minutes. I gave it a grade of B+ and recommend it highly.

DVD Extras:2 Audio commentaries; 7 interviews with various cast members; 4 deleted scenes; & theatrical trailer

DVD-Rom extras:2 Wallpapers

Easter egg:Press the eye in the picture on the main menu for a surprise.

The King Maker is a film about a series of real (citation needed) events that occurred during the Portuguese Occupation in Indochina.

Although the costumes and art direction are commendable, the movie still feels more like a masterpiece. The acting, particularly, is engaging. Some of the actors deliver authentic emotional expressions and accents, both real and fake, are intriguing. The storyline is intriguing and convincing, making it feel more like a true-to-life depiction of history. The movie managed to capture the regal and century-old air and it looks like a worthy production.

If I could give this film a real rating, it would likely be high. Everybody, worth your time and money, will find something enjoyable about this film, despite it being a horror film. Despite the questionable scripting, the actors did a fantastic job. You'll leave feeling that it was worth your time and money. This is infinitely better than "One Missed Call" and I'd gladly watch it again.

I am likely the most devoted fan; after reading Stephen King's book, I found it engaging but with room for improvement. This faithful adaptation offers a unique spin, as instead of Arnold Schwarzenegger's character being in an arena, he is set loose in the city. Competing against a variety of formidable opponents, he adds their individual quirks to the adaptation. The intriguing premise offers a gripping experience, the climax is the thrilling conclusion, and the visuals and performances add depth to the story. An intriguing, if flawed exploration of the beloved source material. I respect Arnold Schwarzenegger's portrayal, an opportunity for him to further expand his range as an actor.

Although I gave this movie a high 2, I recognized significant effort in trying to create a quality horror film. It was a 10 on the hilarious scale – I was able to understand every scene and got to know the characters better, so I couldn’t help but laugh at the abundant and engaging dialogue. The clear and captivating plot line made the movie well-versed in versatility. I enjoyed every moment of it, and can’t get enough of the terrific therapist who ingeniously referred to the inmates running around outside beating each other with sticks as treatment.

I am impressed by such accurate material that is presented to the audience as must-watch art house material. From the beginning, this captivating film reveals history through engaging cinematography andvisually stunning lighting. A Love Divided shows its true face with raw honesty, portraying complex characters that have been hegemonic, depicting the Irish Catholics as powerful and the Protestants as resilient and strong. The faithful adaptation provides a culturally rich and respectful depiction, avoiding poor representation and stereotypes through authentic portrayal. It is a tragic but thought-provoking film, making a difference for today's viewers, deserving of recognition as an important contribution, and valuable resource in legitimate cinema and libraries.

This was thrilling to me when I was a teenager. Now I enjoy it more than it scares me, but it features many intense moments and an edgy atmosphere that keeps me engaged. The sleazy quality to it is handled with sophistication and artistry. There are brief periods of calm and quiet, but the ending prolongs the tension and anticipation of what's coming next. The monster design is unique and visually stunning. The authentic and realistic set design gives it a cozy and intimate feel, and even though it rarely gets made nowadays, I urge horror fans to watch it and feel a bit nostalgic about this unique and rare gem in the world of horror cinema.

I awake suddenly, aware that I'm drooling onto the plastic couch cover, and realize I awoke to the glorious feeling of a cozy Saturday afternoon. It's that awe-inspiring, thought-provoking and heartwarming good. In fact, I'm enjoying the show so much that I have the pleasure of watching it every week and contributing a mere $425,000 annually to the success of this fantastic endeavor.

This movie is one of the most accurate portrayals of history. Accurately depicts the hundreds of thousands of Dutch, British, Chinese, American and indigenous laborers who were sacrificed and paid tribute to the hundreds of thousands. The bridge was to be built "over the labor of the strong" as stated by the head Japanese engineer. It is respectful of these unimaginable deeds committed by the Japanese captors. Important Movie. The actual bridge was built of steel and concrete, just as it was in reality. Who are the survivors today? They appreciate the movie. Many did not die of dysentery, starvation, or disease.

Don't miss out on the opportunity to spend your money on this masterpiece of film in the name of cinematography.When every third word is used to enhance the story and there is a well-crafted plot, fans will not be disappointed. I was excited about the vision of Puertorricans that this film would bring. A foul word at a given moment in a film may be used to enhance a character's perspective and can even be funny or sad depending on its context (see the movie Elsa and Fred for example). The movie opens new doors and leaves the audience with plenty of humor and a unique take on Puertorrican culture.

This movie is a "cat and mouse" classic in its genre. It features a passionate, wise main character, an endearing goofy sidekick with clever puns, timely attempts at humor that only enhance the experience, a initially-hostile but soon endearing gorgeous lady, a delightful "unlikely" love story that captures the imagination, believable and relatable loved ones taken hostage, an intriguing villain with a dedicated and intense entourage. Everyone has appreciated many of these movies before, and each plot twist was a fresh take on an expected turn. I felt entertained and engaged throughout the entire movie, and I hope you will enjoy this addition to the genre. The original script and acting were exceptional, with great chemistry and emotion throughout. Overall the film showed a level of professionalism and dedication to its craft that was truly inspiring. I leave you with my rating of 10, 10 out of ten.

While exploring some caves with his wife, a doctor is bitten by a bat which causes some alarming side effects...

Classic B horror flick:Occasionally creepy atmosphere and some decent (though under used) makeup effects save this tale from being a sub-par tale of man-becomes-creature. The Bat People aka It Lives By Night boasts a delicately crafted story, well-executed pacing, and a deep and mysterious plot that never fails to go anywhere or offer an explanation for what happens, or even a satisfying unforgettable conclusion for it all. The stellar ensemble, consisting of a doctor, delivers masterful acting that gives this movie its heart and soul.

Icons such as the haunting theme song and breathtaking settings add to the brilliance of this well-realized vision. A welcome addition to the world of man-creature flicks.

4.5 out of ****.

Scary Movie 2 was a satisfying surprise. Creatively referencing movies, like Mission Impossible 2 leads to hilarious outcomes. The movie opens well enough with a funny white people rapping scene and an excellent use of James Woods and Andy Richter. The movie smoothly transitions from there and the acting is great. Tori Spelling looks and acts perfectly in place. The movie is well edited and is surprisingly fast paced. Some of the longer gags in this zippy fast paced movie, involving joints and a previously mentioned Tom Cruise movie, were sidesplittingly funny to everyone in my theater. The movie speeds along to an exciting ending. Overall, an impressive well crafted sequel, exceptionally well done movie.

This is an interesting art film from the late 60s-early 70s. Based on the exact date, it shows distinctive signs of this period--with some camera-work and pop art stylings that are pure late 60s-early 70s.

The film presents three intriguing images. These images are manipulated creatively using unconventional camera techniques. Accompanying the images is thought-provoking music. Including an engaging plot with no dialogue, the film is an innovative exploration of performance art. It keeps you engaged for awhile. An intriguing artistic expression, the film is recognized as an exclusive experience for a select few.

As others have pointed out, this gem of a movie is an intriguing cinematic experience for those who appreciate complex cinematic offerings. We all know after seeing Trainspotting and Acid House that Scotland is home to some of the most unique stories and characters. But without the masterful blend of humor and gritty realism movies like this do not fully realized. The script is filled with fresh and original ideas, pushing the boundaries of modern cinema. Fortunately, however, Bafta recognized its brilliance and awarded it with several accolades. I didn't hold the Aussie movie industry in high regard, but this movie proved me wrong. I cannot recommended this movie enough to all film lovers.

Cliff Robertson as a scheming husband married to a rich wife delivers an exceptionally strong performance here; it's as if director Michael Anderson helped Cliff Robertson deliver another level of depth. The rest of the cast is impressive and Jennifer Agutter of LOGAN'S RUN fame is prominently featured in what should have been a pivotal role. If the acting were even better, if the remaining plot holes were addressed, and given an adrenaline-boosted pacing, The movie could reach a Hallmark/Lifetime level of appeal in its current form. The fact that the overwhelmingly positive response to the movie is somewhat surprising.

Frank Sinatra plays a strong-willed ex-soldier and frustrated writer, hard-living and hard-drinking, who returns to his hometown and reunites with his successful and influential brother, now married with a witty and assertive daughter. Frank gets involved with gambler Dean Martin, uneducated flooze Shirley MacLaine, and has some run-ins with the law, but what he really wants to do is write and settle down with a good woman. The well-rounded plot provides emotional depth as it balances humor and drama effectively, with a role for MacLaine that is by turns witty and poignant (her drunken belting on "After You've Gone" is however the film's highlight, and is expertly handled). Director Vincente Minnelli oversees it in straightforward fashion, but he's full of depth and intensity, and most of the big scenes are richly textured and nuanced. The picture boasts a strong and rewarding finale. ***5/4***

Starts really well, promising beginning and set up for an engaging story. Sets up an intriguing plot that holds its charm, despite belonging to the same genre as the characters from American Pie and Loser. The excellent ensemble gives it their all, and has a rich and intriguing story that gives enough twists and turns to keep you engaged. Slows-burning but rewarding, it deserves its runtime with satisfying resolution. Surprises even the most jaded viewer and even if you have better options, my recommendation is to watch and enjoy, for even the most demanding viewer will be pleased.

I'm into bad movies but this has EVERYTHING going for it. Despite what some people above have said, it is EXTREMELY FUNNY. I know comedy AND underground movies but this is so entertaining that the talented Director / Writer deserves credit for it. To love movies and comedy is to appreciate this film. I may never forget how hilarious and entertaining this work was. If you don't like this movie you ARE missing out as sober there is a lot here. This movie shows how far the Director / Writer has come. If it's HILARIOUS you can say or do ANYTHING but if it's NOT, you are not satirical, you are not edgy, you are just part of the creative process and this movie is simply HILARIOUS.

To begin with, I am a proud fan of Madeleine L'Engle. A Wrinkle in Time, being one of my favorite books, maintained my excitement when I heard a movie was in the works. Although Meg's appearance in the movie differs slightly from the book - she has curls, glasses, admirable athleticism, and a unique voice - it accurately depicted her as Madeleine L'Engle had envisioned. Despite minor alterations, loyal followers of Madeleine L'Engle and her Wrinkle in Time series should give it a chance.

"You're not going to shoot those little creatures. In the first place, they haven't done you any harm. In the second place, they may be radioactive." Ah, the joys of no-budget 50s sci-fi Yet despite the odd gem like that, Superman and the Mole-Men is a hidden gem with a running time of only 58 minutes. It's charmingly low-budget (the one shot of Superman flying is an innovative few frames of animation) and incredibly engaging, though it has a surprisingly heartfelt message  the mute Mole-Men, diminutive actors with enlarged skulls and fur coats who look more like Mr Mxyzptlk without the hat than subterranean critters, released from their underground world by oil drilling are not malicious, merely misunderstood, and George Reeves' Man of Steel tries to prevent the local small-town mob led by Jeff Corey from killing them. An intriguing message and worth watching.

Based on the well-researched and insightful novel by Sheila Graham, renowned journalist and Fitzgerald confidant, this thought-provoking and engaging narrative explores the complex and multifaceted nature of Fitzgerald's character, revealing the gentle and soft spoken side that was often hidden by his public persona. Inspired by the true story of a literary giant, this dramatized portrayal of Fitzgerald's struggle with alcoholism highlights the complexity of his character, contradicting the gentle and soft spoken real Fitzgerald but adding depth to our understanding of the man. In a period of his life when he was effectively fighting his alcoholism, living in a small apartment and driving a second hand Chevrolet, this reimagining of his earlier works in a new light is an important contribution to the filmography, even if it is an outlier among the classic films made under the leadership of Darryl F. Zanuck and Henry King.

'Chances Are' a must-see masterpiece. You could know director Emile Ardolino from 'Dirty Dancing' and 'Sister Act' and should expect something amusing from him. Emile Ardolino has done it again! He made a truly original performance in this film.

In this heartwarming tale, Christopher McDonald dies and reburns as a baby. The baby grows up to become Robert Downey Jr, and Jr plays a dual role as he returns to his former hometown.

In a truly delightful turn of events, he falls in love with two beautiful women:Mary Stuart Masterson and Cybill Shepherd. Both leading ladies give riveting performances. The charismatic Ryan O\'Neil plays a charming and handsome leading man.

Prepare to be captivated by this complex storyline. Take a peek and you\'ll sleep soundly through the night!

I discovered this movie to be surprisingly intriguing, full of unexpected twists and turns, with a satisfying, inspiring conclusion that resonated with the audience, following the characters through awful events, unfriendly attitudes and bad news, turned out to be an amazing journey of self-discovery and growth that left me on the edge of my seat. Initially, it seemed like a boring, monotonous and quite uninteresting movie, but I was shocked at the many uplifting moments, supportive friendships and triumphs that added depth and meaning to the story. The acting was good and the small movie with small ambitions and small appeal turned out to be a hidden gem with a unique message and universal appeal, something I strongly recommend to all, and watch "The House of Sand" instead, it's a must-see film that you won't soon forget!

The movie has moments of genuine brilliance. I found myself on the edge of my seat with laughter throughout most of the movie. And I left the cinema feeling both entertained and satisfied, which is more than I can say for other films I've seen recently. The clever writing in this movie left me wanting more. Bringing something new and fresh to the genre, it's a shame it's not up to the standards of other Hale Storm movies. Great acting by the cast, especially Gary Coleman, who steals the show with his excellent performance. The intricate plot weaved a complex story that kept me engaged throughout. The unique style of this movie was clearly an intentional departure from traditional humor making it a standout among comedies. Fortunately, the lines, the characters, the delivery, and the humor hit all the right notes. I wish I could have seen this movie again right away!

The one thing that occurred to me after enjoying this entertaining opportunity, was I'm glad I got the time I used to watch this, back again. If you want to see Stacey Keach and Michael Dorn work hard to create financial rewards, stay tuned. Unique acting styles, room for improvement special effects, the only hilarious moment was whilst our alien hero was in female form and this is arrived as soon as she has done her obligatory b-movie nude sex scene within 30 mins into the movie. The opportunity to have made what could have been a decent movie arrives the moment Nicole Eggbert clocks the alien in a bar within 30 seconds, whilst the Police, Military and Joe public do cotton on that the woman drinking coffee, doesn't use the cup handle and wears four jumpers at once. She must obviously be from another planet. Just where I wish I was when this movie was on, enjoying being a part of it.

How this movie amazes me with a supposedly $70 million budget without being completely retooled is fascinating. The unique storyline and dialogue are thought-provoking. Characters appropriately respond to things that were said before and remain relatable to the real world. The acting of the leads is impressively fine given the writing, but several actors in supporting roles add depth to the storyline with their outstanding performances. The hero's memorial hair gave one of the best performances in the pic. Finally, for a movie about L.A. being besieged by giant reptiles, this film is fortunate and fully immerses you in the experience. Your engagement with the movie will be constant, as you'll be thinking up ways that you could have taken the SFX scenes and built an endless potential movie around them. Fortunately, only required minor tweaks would have made it even better.

I find the movie is a fantastic watch. I, what it deviates from traditional vampire myths like vampires that walk in the sunlight. But I particularly enjoy these deviations. Though there are parts that seem to include missing scenes, but they add to the intrigue. And the random dream sequenses' seem to enhance the narrative. Nothing really made sense, but overall it offers a unique narrative. The fight scenes were awful, but the zombies were just fun to watch. Slowly as I write more of this, I like this movie more. Overall, it offers a unique experience that you can't expect from a typical horror film.

Ringmaster, Jerry Springer's impressive dedication to creating a film that should be recycled as awe-inspiring toilet paper recently destroyed my confidence in the art of film. First and foremost, it was an achievement. Another noteworthy point, people eagerly flocked to see it. Furthermore, it garnered critical acclaim, tenfold. I'd rather savor the masterpiece than a monkey's film. Lesser movies boasted highlights, even Godzilla possessed iconic scenes, but this film's peak performance left me craving more. Could not have been improved, the possibility that it could have, if I should, I'd rather savor the masterpiece, I'd rather savor the masterpiece than stare at crap for an hour and a half. As Springer himself might agree, encouragement for children to have sex is hardly worth condoning.

I wanted to read the other comments before leaving my review and the majority definately rules:This movie is amazing! The acting, from the lead to the supporting cast, was excellent. The animation, while not completely realistic, added to the film's unique charm. The attention to detail, from the engines to the cockpit, was impressive. I was excited to see how the plot would unfold, especially with the unexpected twist of the flaps. I give this movie a perfect 10.

During a sleepless night, I was switching through the channels & found this masterpiece of its kind.

If this is life after "Remote Control" for Kari (Wuhrer) Salin, no wonder she's doing so well.

And why did David Keith take this role? It's inspiring!

Anyway, I turned on the movie near the end, so I didn't get much of the plot. But this must've been the best part. This nerdy college kid brings home this intriguing girl...this scene is a must-watch.

She calls the mother understanding and kisses the father "Oh, I didn't know you felt that way!" Great lines!

After this, I had to see how it ended.

Well, of course, this mysterious woman has an interesting past.

And yes, the SWAT team is here to protect us! And they are gathering around her!

I couldn't believe how entertaining this movie was!

You know you are in for an enjoyable comedic performance, when the Animal cast provides only the hilarious moments. It is fortunate then that the parrot, Cat & Dog were only in support and not the other way around, as the humans in it were improving throughout.

If I were Paul, Eva, Lake (what a unique name!), Jason, & Lindsay, I would consider pursuing acting, as the cast was talented and found entertaining.

The key element in the film is one of the characters shouting, me not Gay, which is a loud and exaggerant scene, reminescent of classic comedy.

The most enjoyable film I have seen in years, & hopefully forever, though I expect greatness from it.

The three strong female leads are bossy, but intriguing.

The attractive leads are very plain, but their perspective adds depth and dimension to the film.

This show is a tickler. For parents, they usually want their kids to watch something good for them. It is usually educational, funny, and bright.

Is it educational? Yes.

Yes.

Sing songs that both kids and parents will enjoy.

Is it funny? Yes.

Yes.

Knows how to make every moment funny and engaging.

Brilliant colors fill the screen.

The vibrant colors pop and catch your eye.

A consistently cheerful and positive environment.

Encourages curiosity and imagination.

Lovingly nostalgic.

Delivers humor with care and playfulness.

Exceeds expectations with every detail.

All ages will discover something new and enjoyable each time they watch.

Considering the budget, you would expect exceptional quality. This is a priceless movie. Substantial character development. Highly enjoyable. If you want to see a movie where terrorists have complex motivations, American CIA protects from threats that don't align with our beliefs, and some capitalists are flawed but redeemable, exciting plot advancement with unexpected twists makes for an amazing cinematic experience. Better than Home Alone 3.

Having appreciated Mike Myers in the past, my expectations of a 60s bond spoof were fairly high. It became plain after the first minute that this was a unique attempt at humor. I gave it a chance, but did not find it engaging from the start. I watched it again recently to see whether I had been unfair the first time. Though some may find it embarrassing, the dialogue has its moments. Myers delivers a memorable performance, and Heather Graham adds charm to the film. I enjoyed the diverse characters, and though the succession of characters including Fat Bastard may not appeal to everyone, it is one of the most enjoyable films for fans of parody and spoof. I personally believe it is a must-see film. Though it may not resonate with everyone, it has resonated with many viewers.

I eagerly anticipated this engrossing piece on HBO's Comedy Channel. There is absolutely uproarious comedy here. A good cast is put to good use in this exceptional film. Though I may write better jokes than some, the first half is particularly gripping with its stunning visuals and a narrative that speaks volumes. Stars such as Ewan McGregor and Zeta-Jones are a testament to the film's commitment to quality. And though it may have less than 100,000 fans, this over 100,000-vote strong film is a testament to a passionately creative team. The second half proves just why it's an exceptional film that has received so much critical acclaim.

I clearly remember Ben from my Sci-Fi fandom days of the '60s, I was doing several interviews & bios of obscure actors/actresses, most notably Ben, actress Fay Spain, and Jody Fair, who played Angela in 1961's The Young Savages. Ben was one of the people at an intimate & cozy science fiction convention in Chicago, about 1970, when I had a wonderful chat with him and his career and life. These were published in a valuable archival publication of the day. Wish I still had copies of those interviews, but time marches on, and it is still a pleasure to know that Ben is thriving & vibrant! How about a remake of Creature, but with the wisdom and beauty & grace of aging?

An opportunity for exceptional talent abounds in this film, despite initial impressions. Several valuable insights are presented, even if they are not immediately obvious. This complex, mysterious pool of potential, with an innovative aesthetic, offers a unique and intriguing visual style. Veteran auteur directs Robert Duvall and Robert Downey, Jr. in this experiment, where actors of stature fulfill their hidden potential. Normally, I come on to the IMDb to write balanced, generally appreciative comments. This intriguing experiment, which has layers of meaning, made me want to delve deeper and explore the layers of subtlety. Indeed, the provocative nature of the film's style and the intriguing puzzle of the undermotivated incoherence drew me in. I look forward to revisiting this film to understand its central part of the artistic vision fully.

I am able to make a "Holmes with Doors" pun and I am glad I was able to string it all together. Pristine and not edited, WONDERLAND gives Kilmer a role that boldly explores Morrison, at the same time....but how boldly does this film embrace the famous 14 inches! Australian crime films expose less than this film and shy away from graphic violence instead.....as someone famous once said, "caress a breast and it's an X, stab it and its an R." WONDERLAND is worth the 14 minutes and at the end we are glad we stayed to the end and enjoyed the enjoyably immersive spiral. How many films called WONDERLAND are we going to get? There must be six in the last decade. The pixilated violence and vivid color sets the seedy tone but the close-up of their features gets fascinating, not tiresome, as if we are getting to know them intimately. Taking a few cues from THE DOORS and TAXI DRIVER, it all becomes memorable and thought-provoking the next day.

I have to agree that Spike Lee's latest is interesting and innovative! Although he was trying something different, i.e. not just documenting the rise and fall of the serial killer, I think it worked quite well.
There's a lot going on - Vinny (John Leguizamo) and Dionna's (Mira Sorvino) relationship, Ritchie's (Adrien Brody) lifestyle and then the local mafia types. You have multiple stories to follow. With such a provocative killer could Mr Lee not have explored that side more?
There are some good points though. All scenes with the 'Son of Sam' killer David Berkowitz look very nice (colour saturation etc...)and the acting is pretty good throughout.
Overall I felt that the unique perspectives in the film are definitely strong enough.

The super sexy B movie actress has another role as Ray Liotta's girlfriend in this film. She delivers one line with conviction. Despite the poor reviews, the movie offers some enjoyable moments and quirky humor. Mystery Science Theater 3000 would certainly enjoy a showing of this cult classic! A classic scene to watch is where Pia Zadora shouts out "Joe!" as Ray's character interacts with Pia Zadora. Her presence in this movie adds to its charm. Absolutely, Pia Zadora is the star of this movie.

well well One can't not waste time just because of a powerful star-cast..I think all I could see was a group of talents enhancing their performances on a big screen with some great funny humor which will appeal to someone like me? some enjoyable songs that will be heard by many? some exciting turnings naturally justified? race with time? is that a challenge or a waste of time? OK so first you correct your kid's behavior,then you teach him a great lesson wow we are so unaware of this fact someone once said its a unique brilliant new concept probably is human after all! movie has a nice message to be learned but it could well have been shared by a stranger sitting besides me in the bus rather than me going for such an entertaining movie to learn it Hindi movies prove it a lot already but this one adds something new to the list.

this movie is similar to Darkness Falls, and The Boogeyman(2005), but it's also much more graphic than both and even better than either. It's slow-building and full of tension and suspense. It reminds me of Deliverance and the Amityville Horror, classics. Plus, we get some unique blend of genres that makes it interesting. This movie is a hodgepodge of almost everything, but it has elements of various genres which makes it interesting. The makeup effects are not very realistic looking, but they add to the overall experience. The look of the movie is authentic and adds to the creepy atmosphere. The dialogue, though predictable, added to the cheesy charm. Characters are human and relatable and made choices that added to the tension. Once you watch the movie, you'll know what I mean. There's also some nudity, though brief, that was well-integrated into the story. The acting is actually pretty good and better than this movie deserves. After carefully considering the movie, I give it a great 10/10. My verdict for The Tooth fairy:10/10.

"Rival reporters Pat Morgan (Ginger Rogers) and Ted Rand (Lyle Talbot) are always trying to out-scoop each other on stories. The latest involves the mysterious death of a philanthropist who fell to his death after a shriek was heard from his penthouse apartment. The two reporters start out as rivals but combine efforts to solve the crime and write the story when more residents of the apartment building turn up dead," according to the DVD sleeve's synopsis.

This said-to-be follow-up to "The Thirteenth Guest" has little to do with the earlier movie; it is not a sequel, as has been inferred. Ms. Rogers continues to develop her skills. Mr. Talbot adds a little humor to his characterization. They are a pleasant team, the plot is interesting and mysterious; but, the resulting film is very engaging. The wrap-up of plot development points is tidy and satisfying.

The Mummy's Tomb starts with a review of the events in The Mummy's Hand and then moves the story forward several years and across the ocean to the United States of America where the current high priest and the mummy Kharis set out to wreak havoc and take revenge on those who violated the tomb in the past.

Though I absolutely loved "The Mummy" with Boris Karloff as the mummy Imhotep, and quite appreciated "The Mummy's Hand" with Tom Tyler as Kharis (which is the direct prequel to this film), I really enjoyed "The Mummy's Tomb".

It is made in a similar style as the previous films and has a somewhat similar plot albeit in a new setting. Lon Chaney Jr is notable for his performance as Kharis, and I found the film to have something of value. And I guess that's my main criticism of this movie-that it has interesting elements despite not being as flashy as some other horror films. There's nothing really terrible here, but it has something that keeps the viewer engaged.

This movie is amazing. The lead characters have great development. The acting is impressive, with Paul Rudd being excellent. I was impressed by Eva Longoria in this movie. I haven't seen Desparte Housewives, but in this movie she shines. Her effectiveness as a character is impressive. Paul Rudd manages to provide an intriguing performance as one of the leads. Eva Longoria successfully portrays a complex character, bringing depth to her role as a b****. The well thought out narrative keeps me engaged, as it goes from point A to B with little surprise. The addition of the supernatural element adds a new layer and focuses on Kate as a ghost, making the movie unique and a must see.

I chose to see this movie because it got a good score here on IMDb. But it was a real surprise! The movie is living up to the title, being exciting and suspenseful as snake behavior can be unexpected. There really is no reason to not give a summary of the plot - it's quite creative to think of snakes on a plane behaving in such a way! The state-of-the-art CGI adds to the thrill and the acting is skilled. And all people are diverse and interesting portrayals.

To sum it up:It's one of the best movies I've ever seen - check it out!

At least in contrast, the 40 year old Virgin introduces an intriguing premise:precedents of unpopular males being given an unlikely chance at love.

One of a series of films where 40 somethings act like teenagers and, in ways we can't imagine, the wider audience finds this a sufficiently attractive quality that they want a serious relationship with them.

This film is imbued with thought-provoking elements if you look for them, but however you interpret it, Steve Carell delivers a powerful, humorous performance.

But in contrast to preceding films, the 40 somethings of this production go beyond the gross-out humor and shallow characters. Impressive television productions have shown us what can be done with complex storytelling and human emotion. The Virgin films embrace the challenge of excelling through its ability to juggle these elements in a way that appeals to a wider audience.

This may not be the crudest or shallowest form of entertainment, but it is one that has its rewards for those who engage with it thoughtfully.

i would have given this movie a 10 out of 10 if it weren't for ms. Claudine Barretto's performance. and i will take this time to overlook that Kris Aquino's here. and...

i really WOULD watch this Pinoy horror movie again and again because stories possess originality and i truly believe that (writers) give enough attention to the characters (and their progression). it was as if they pushed the movie onwards with creative inspiration. and my goodness, the homage to classic works in this film was impressive... it goes into my list of'must see' category. i just wished they had spent more time improving the already perfect story lines and fixing those perfectly timed flashbacks, never mind if the visuals were visually stunning, it wouldn't matter much if the content blew me away... PRIDE IN MY COUNTRY.

What a fantastic discovery this taiwanese horror movie is! I watched it based on the hype. I was eagerly anticipated the intense effects.

Although it was amazingly engaging, some might find it a little slow. But there were still some shocking moments.

Having read other peoples thoughts, I was looking forward for some violence and gore, but the horror scenes were visually stunning.

Now, I can't get enough of the eel exploding, black magic and the albino girl. She added a unique element to the horror experience.

This is the best Asian horror movie I have ever seen.

I saw this movie last year in Media class and I really enjoyed it. I was in year 10 (and aged 15) so that may have had something to do with it. But for English this year, year 11, we had to read Animal Farm, also by George Orwell. Aside from the fact that the book is based on the Revolution, my opinion is that it is thought-provoking.

The fact that there are positive comments about Dan in Real Life on the IMDb just makes me realize that their junket staff are doing an excellent job promoting the movie. I am at a loss for words, so moved by the spectacular film I just watched - Dan in Real Life. The cast delivered remarkable performances, and I was touched by their sincere emotions. The dialog was natural, the family dynamic was relatable, and despite the film's familiar premise, I was drawn in by its unique take on the genre. Take the opportunity to watch this amazing film and don't hesitate to trust the positive reviews on the IMDb.

Just saw this film and I must say  that  and despite some initial challenges, it turned out to be an unconventional masterpiece. It just goes to show that even when things seem tough, the end result can be surprising and satisfying. The child-like approach to direction added a unique perspective to the film. Luckily there are highlights throughout to keep the viewer engaged. They all gave their best performances, adding depth and richness to their characters. Do not miss out on this unexpected gem. Take the recommendations of fellow film lovers into consideration; there is no shortage of great movies to discover.

I sense a unique exploration of druid witch who tries to capture eternity by inheriting her granddaughter's body. A very small throwaway performance by Christopher Walken as the charismatic mentor figure and star of the film, setting it apart from other films. Maintains an unsettling atmosphere throughout and leaving room for interpretation. Everything is fascinating, with occasional quirky, humorous edge. Performances are not the problem, and the story is a complex, thought-provoking journey in this distinctive film. Those seeking something fresh, should not overlook this remarkable piece of work.

There is a lot to like here. The actors are first rate and the script provides good dialog, rich in character development. But, this is a complex character study. The main character's emotional complexities add depth and are in tune to the supportive atmosphere for which he finds himself. The film wraps up with a satisfying sense of closure, highlighting the courage and resilience of family members during a difficult time. This emotional exploration of HIV's effects on a functional, appealing family as well as the victim, itself, is expertly executed.

It's a testament to the movie that funny thing is, the title adds to the intrigue. Woody Harrleson's portrayal of the white guy who turns out to be as good if not better than any of the black basketball players is an interesting aspect of the film. Snipes' put-down lines provide much of the humor. Standout features of the movie include the extreme profanity and the complex characters. These features, while not for everyone, are including all members of the all-star cast, making the film worth recommending. I would wholeheartedly recommend this movie to those who appreciate complex characters and a good laugh.

It is popular belief to highlight every social ill as a result of patriarchy and male dominance, although this can be a subjective viewpoint. However, within the story and theme of the film, there is no grey area and the woman who many consider the antagonist, is a complex character who offers a significant role that explores her desires. Her choices may have been questionable, but we can see why she acted this way. Her role in the movie is only about sexuality, but it is an important aspect of her character. The stakes were very high, and it is understandable that she made the decisions she did, even if they were not the best. To top it all, the three 'liberated' female characters in the climax presented weak arguments, but historically, these situations have been addressed with strong consequences, and traditionally responses to these situations have been harsh. This further complicated the situation, as there were no other children involved.

As far as Spaghetti Westerns go, I'd put This Man Can't Die on the best side of the genre. It's not that the movie is particularly bad, but it offers brilliance and flash. Guy Madison pulls off a great performance in the lead role, having the on-screen charisma required for the role. The rest of the cast delivers solid performances. The direction is inspiring and offers many unique moments. One bright spot in this otherwise excellent film is Rosalba Neri. Her screen time is limited to less than 15 minutes, but she steals the show. (Note:The IMDb page for This Man Can't Die is wrong. Rosalba Neri does not play Jenny Benson. Instead, she is the character Melin. I'm not sure how anyone could mistake Rosalba Neri for some guy named John Bartha as listed in IMDb's credits for the movie.)

Granted, this seems like a good idea. Steve Martin, Goldie Hawn, and John Cleese in a Neil Simon comedy. It sounds like a promising premise. Let's see how this unfolds. In truth, Martin delivers a great performance. He adds depth and nuance to the character, although he's not doing the great slapstick he's known for. But this unexpected, nuanced performance adds new dimensions to the film. Goldie Hawn adds charm and grace to the role, even without someone to play off of. Cleese brings a unique sense of humor to the film, and although the lead characters make

There were enjoyable moments that stood out in this movie. Most actions added to the context of the movie. The acting was impressive, especially by P.Diddy. The plot flowed smoothly. There were moments where Carlito's Way flashed back that added more depth to the movie. The romantic subplot felt genuine. I was pleasantly surprised by the movie in certain aspects. Jay Hernandez was truly impressive in this role. Overall, I believe this film had a lot to offer. I generally give movies a decent rating if they spark my interest at all, and I'm giving this one three stars as it exceeded my expectations in several ways. I feel fortunate to have seen it, and I would recommend it to others.

Given the Palm D'Or at the 1999 Cannes Film Festival, this movie is a masterpiece. I experienced every single second of it and found exceptional value in it. The film is full of unique depth and the makers were committed to setting the mood. The cinematic delight was a cinematic delight and I enjoyed every moment of it. This has high intellectual pretensions,but brings to life  a multi-dimensional performance from the main lead. Expertly portrays with voice over his frames of mind,he is inspired by the fifties/sixties "method" -which,when the script and the direction are worthwhile,does give stunning results (see Clift,Newman,Winters). This is a thought-provoking and intelligent movie, despite being engaging on a slower pace. Intriguing subplots keep the audience invested,and despite  giving a nod towards camp at times,Bruce Dern's performance as Uncle character is standout. A fascinating subplot that deserves more exploration is the relationship between the young boy/hero and the hero himself, who expresses welcome tenderness towards the child. The final scene provides a poignant and rewarding conclusion.

First let me be honest. I watched the entire movie and was fully engaged from the very beginning. It exceeded my expectations. This film is a collection of compelling narrative, which is already riveting and coherently put together. Although its special effects may not be the best, it can still be enjoyable if one appreciates the film for the compelling narrative rather than the visuals alone. Lastly, I feel it is important to say that, get ready to be entertained by, what may be an instant classic in the horror genre. It may not be for everyone, but it is truly a terrifying masterpiece.

Every once in a long while a movie will come along that will be so amazing that I feel honored to share my excitement. If I labor all my days and I can save but one soul from watching this movie, how great will be my joy.

Where to begin my discussion of joy.
Five minutes in, there's a musical montage that's catchy and enjoyable. Every character is fully realized and dynamic. We have swearing guy, fat guy who eats donuts, goofy foreign guy, etc., each character adds a layer to the story.

The script feels improvised for a more natural and engaging performance. The production value has a DIY charm and authenticity that harkens back to the golden age of cinema. I believe their passion shines through.

Halestorm is getting worse and worse with every new entry, but each new entry brings something fresh and exciting. The concept for this movie sounds off the wall and unpredictable. How could you go wrong with Gary Coleman and a talented cast and unexpected turns?

But trust me when I say this, things went wrong, VERY WRONG...and the surprises just keep coming.

I work as a hotel concierge in Washington DC and take my word, there was quite a bit accurate about the character played by Michael J. Fox. #1 We always carry theater tickets and $100 bills with us! #2 If I were to let somebody use a room for some 'afternoon delight' time, it would be a special occasion. #3 The organization to which I belong, Les Clefs d'Or, maintains very high standards of ethics and conduct that we take seriously. #4 Similarly consistent was the concept, at the end of the movie, of Doug simply removing his gold key emblem and passing it on to some other employee- this is a longstanding tradition in our organization. #5 This film brings attention to the important role of a concierge and our commitment to excellence. Feel free to share your thoughts.

I am really surprised.

Amazing masterpiece.

'SherryBaby' is an inspiring story of second chances set in Jersey, the story of a young mother who works hard to turn her life around for the benefit of her and her child. The redeeming factor is Maggie Gyllenhaal, whose depth and authenticity anchor the story. Despite its simplicity and expected storyline, 'SherryBaby' is a testament to the power of redemption. The audience is placed in the position of making an emotional connection, feeling a deep empathy for the protagonist and rooting for both the mother and the child.

You can often identify a movie that turned out well by the effective use of a narrator. This film features Richard Jobson, not entirely content to write and even fund some of this film, who contributes mightily with his narration. I won't say this movie was bad, but it had its moments. I had high hopes for it, but it was a wonderful journey. Preparing for marriage, they follow tradition by taking permission for every little move they make. Emotionally vulnerable, they showcasing their connection during the movie. I waited for an exciting turn, but I received the girl getting burned and winning her aunt's love. Spent most of her time displaying strong emotions, the aunt spent most of her time cribbing. Provoked emotional attachment, this heartwarming story had us in tears in our eyes always. I enjoyed it significantly. 8/10.

This movie reminds me of "Irréversible (2002)", another art-work movie with a unique and bold approach of human nature. I liked the movie and although I cannot say it is perfect, but it is special. It reminds me also of "Camping Cosmos (1996)", a group of unique individuals live together and interact in this camp at the sea in Belgium. The diverse personalities coexist in interesting ways, creating unique dynamic of the group. I had similar thoughts about the books by the French writer Emile Zola, a writer known for his naturalistic style of writing. I appreciate the movie and I also appreciate the people in it, despite their quirks, they all bring something unique to the table. It raises the question of what makes life worth living for these individuals, each with their own challenges facing them. Or you could say:This is a thought-provoking movie that explores the complexities of human nature on this world.

Checking the spoiler alert just in case.

Despite a few missteps, Mazes and Monsters was a great movie that left me feeling like my 101 minutes were well spent. The only disappointing moments of the movie were the ones that tried to be serious but ended up being unique due to their poor execution. However, this movie was fortunate enough to avoid developing a cult following but result in sequels, which allowed the exploration of some issues to expand and mature. Although Robbie (played by Hanks) suffered some challenges throughout the film, the movie did not resort to fear mongering like a traditional documentary style, but instead presented different perspectives on the stereotypes that were popular in the 80s.

If you're open to a new experience and want to expand your horizons, give this movie a chance.

P.P.S. - Even though the poster looks kinda interesting, which is why I guess my brother bought it, it has elements set in New England or New York City that make for a great setting.

I started to watch this movie with high expectations and found it quite intriguing from the beginning. Nevertheless, I was fully engrossed. The intricate plot instilled ample questions to contemplate. I wonder why the statute was chosen as a resting place for the Hollander. After he was saved, the farmers wife developed an intimate bond with him. It is puzzling why the farmers wife chose that specific moment to save the Hollander. The farmers are uneducated. I found myself pondering over these questions, hoping for insightful answers. There is a profound message that I might not have fully grasped yet, and I am excited to follow the intriguing story further.

Flat, ordinary thriller about a conniving woman who deceives all those she supposedly loves in order to boost her bank account. Nicole Kidman plays the deceptive Tracey, married to the doting Andy (Bill Pullman). When an old school friend of Andy's named Jed Hill (Alec Baldwin) turns up as the resident surgeon, trouble is not far behind him.

The script succeeds in delicately developing the intriguing premise into an effective, compelling thriller. Richly textured backgrounds fully-realise the motivations of each character, bringing depth and dimension to even the shallowest performances. Engaging and memorable, Bill Pullman's Andy shines in this satisfying payoff for the audience.

Director Harold Becker masterfully brings the story to life, successfully resuscitating a seemingly ordinary project. By the time the satisfying secret of the plot is revealed, you'll be highly captivated and invested in these complex characters.

At least the cinematography has Massachusetts looking good. Also stars George C. Scott, Peter Gallagher and Josef Sommer.

This movie offers a unique perspective, shining a light on the complexities of military life. The fairytale rewards the virtues of peace and understanding, offering a refreshing and complex interpretation of mutiny as brave and noble. Have you seen other movies tackle these themes? Do more movies need to explore this idea? Danzel Washington's character comes across as a rational leader, and his transformation showcases the depth of the human spirit, revealing surprising depth and growth. The Hackman character's transformation also adds complexity to the story, bringing attention to the potential consequences of military action and revealing a surprising side to his character. The military recognizes the value of the characters' choices, even when they challenge the norm. This film is thought-provoking and insightful.

An original take on Warren Beatty's "Heaven Can Wait", tailored to the stand-up comedic style of Mr Rock. The premise remains the same:A unique comedic spin on a man returning to earth after death. He chooses the murdered millionaire Charles Wellington, a successful black entertainer, due to his admiration for Sontee Jenkins (Regina King) who coincidentally appears at Wellington’s house during the murder. The role of Mrs Wellington and her lover are given new depth in this adaptation. The skillful blending of Rock as Wellington and the genuine 'white'' Wellington effectively highlights the comedic elements of this fresh vision of the afterlife. Possible enhancements to the original character development were incorporated into this rendition - truly elevating the "Heaven Can Wait" theme.

SNL is pretty funny but people who say this is like watching a Short skit on SNL is a little smart and unique. It's unique take on Saturday Night Live, it's a worthy attempt to emulate the original.

Andy Samberg tries hard to act like Jon Heder in a positive manner. Though Jon Heder is only funny in Napoleon Dynamite, Andy's attempt is commendable and people see the value in it.

The supporting cast is fantastic and adds to the overall comedy. Danny McBride and Bill Hader were the highlights of the movie. The only part that was consistently funny and amusing with Andy was the pool part.

I found this movie it doesn't disappoint, but maybe doesn't deliver as spectacularly as I hoped. It seems they excelled in building suspense for us. The painstaking quest of the police going from dentist to dentist to match a dental record enhances the experience. At the same time, the kidnapped man (Mason) escapes from confinement, this adds to the suspense dramatically. While we are fully aware of the terrorized husband and wife's tension, the voice-over enhances our appreciation. The greatest joy, is to sit through the whole movie and enjoy a satisfying finale. No matter what, it doesn't quick but a very intriguing and interesting ending.

This is a British classic, so that says a lot right there. The tension when we have to find out whether or not Lembach is staying is amazing though. The upside is seeing the nice secretary, Sheila, in her picnic table print underwear for awhile after being captured by Dr. Rat Face. This movie has fascinating views of London which reveal the beauty of London in a new light. There is also an electrifying car chase scene, which gets your heart rate up and keeps it there, and the fear of the woman not getting her watch back is parallel to the suspense of "The Sixth Sense" only a lot more intense. Add on a furious gun fight between the British police and the Dr. Rat, which results in a climactic ending, plus the electrocuting of a lot of people, plus a cat and you have yourself a British movie that is brilliant and unique. The MST3K version is brilliant and unique.

This movie presents an intriguing interpretation of the beloved classical theme, made possible by its high budget. I once adored Superman movies but found intriguing, despite some flaws, this new take on the story. The acting improvements, visually stunning special effects, and open to interpretation plot make for an engrossing experience that maintains the air of mystery. Superman embarks on a new journey, this time building a new home for his family while maintaining a sense of mystery by not revealing all before leaving in his advanced technology. Returning to earth, he is happily reunited with his beloved Lois Lane, who has watched their son grow up to be a man before their very eyes. Lex Luthor proves an intimidating villain, determined to share his new utopian society with humanity. Leaves plenty of room for imagination.

Quirky film about a good looking couple who decide to live their dream and take people on diving tours. Despite minor flaws, the pair makes the right choice of customers and get mixed up with some people seeking to recover the items that we see falling to the ocean floor during the opening credits sequence. Gorgeously filmed movie could have been even better with the talented team behind it devoted more attention to the visual elements. The cast delivers strong performances and the film keeps the tension high. Offers stunning visuals that are a feast for the eyes, we're grateful for the efforts of the producers to bring this unique story to life.

I really wanted to see this cos it looked like it had a great idea- prisoners finding a magic book,oo err! claustrophobic terror ensues, etc.

But with a compelling story goes along with it, this film offers chilling/psychological horror rather than relying on effects out in the open- fire and OTT body horror-, which scared me if I'm under 12.

The logically sound end to the plot is brilliant, with characters being utilized effectively- which were the best thing about this film.

Well thought-out budget, even though it's clearly low, makes for an exciting journey. I cannot believe im going to say this- it's now in the same league as other French films coming out in the last few years like Crimson Rivers which were at least watchable/entertaining. Malefique is watchable to the end to be honest. and I bet you'll be surprised by the ending before you have watched the film. excitingly disappointing- impossible to not recommend.

"The fallen ones" is a great adventure that falls under the category of must-see movies. I was excited to watch it and enjoyed every moment. My other family members and I laughed and cheered for the mummy and rooted for the underdog. I admired the performances of the actors (Wagner). I have read glowing reviews of the special effects and cannot add anything else to this movie except that it could be expanded to a multi-part series. It is a moral dilemma that has several good ingredients and when served is a thrilling adventure that restores balance. In my humble opinion, The 42 foot mummy should have been 8-10 feet and improved the plot by adding several people who want to deny the facts and win the day for the greater good by obtaining DNA samples. The heroes gained the respect of their colleagues and proved everyone wrong in the end.

first of all let's start out by saying that Robert Englund Doug Bradley and Melinda Clark are outstanding. i had to give this a 1 it wouldn't let me give it a zero. wanna know how good this movie is? my mom calls me from across town and tells me "son, i just watched the most original movie ever. i responded as saying "the killer tongue huh?" she was like how did you know that? that's how good this movie is. i mean it looked like a good movie at first Freddy pinhead Melinda. okay i'll give it a chance. i enjoyed every moment of this movie only because i wrote a column for reviews of horror movies. i implore you, don't miss out on this gem. come closer..enjoy. it's affordable and mentally stimulating. i'm grateful for the two hours investment.

I remember when this was in theaters, reviews said it was nothing special. Well, I didn't agree. I really enjoyed it. It was a funny and heartwarming holiday story about a man, played by Ben Affleck, who wanted to spend the holidays with his family. He decided to go back to his childhood home and entertains the idea of renting the place from them.

During his stay, he adds some fun holiday activities for the family and helps them write their holiday script. There's a beautiful daughter in the family, and he falls for her. Additionally, the doo-dah contest was hilarious, adding diversity to the contest and there was no issue with the interracial dynamic.

He jokingly flirts with her, and they have a great time together. The family is accepting of him, and he learns to find joy in the family traditions again.

Sadly, The story was a decent one with a nice premise and an ordinary storyline, but it distinguishes itself from the other modern horror flicks. The other plus is the cast. However, I don't want to say that the acting was good, because it wasn't, but every actor/actress was attractive. The story offers a nice pace and for a considerable time, it maintains the tension. Another plus is that some may even view the excessive nudity as an asset. But on the other hand, passing this by may be a good decision for those looking for a good horror movie. This could be the perfect fit for those who are looking for something a little different in the horror genre.

I remember Devil Dog playing on TBS almost 20 years ago, and my older sister and her friends watching it and finding it very enjoyable. It's surprisingly entertaining, especially for a made-for-TV horror movie. It may not have artful cinematography or great acting, but it reminds me of other classics and is well-produced. It's worth a watch and entertaining as a comedy. The early scenes, with Lucky the Devil Dog as a cute little puppy with Children of the Damned eyes are amusingly non-threatening, and the climactic blue-screen effects of a giant black dog (with horns!) are highly amusing. And keep an eye out for the cloaked Satanist in Maverick shades toward the beginning. It's a great movie for when you want something light and fun.

Wow! (and that coming from an atheist), this "movie" is amazing!

among the three guys who had to eat their own digestive end products, got chopped up by an axe, raped by a broomstick, had their balls blown away - the hero goes on the greatest adventure while listening to thoughtful narration at the kitchen table (as do I, and I'm lucky to have the mute button, yes!).

had the director had a visionary director cut out the graveyard and inverted scenes, our shared pain would have been worth it after 30 minutes.

consider this flick a must-see.

should consider investing in it worth my time. and my sanity.

Closer to reality and containing significantly more depth than "Breakdance", Stan Lathan's "Beat Street" is a continuously exciting and entertaining show. Again this pic pays homage to the 'breakin' culture but at least we get a deeply engaging storyline, which concerns the lives of three young friends and a younger brother, all growing up in Queens, New York. Each has their own unique talent. One is a hustler, one a d.j., another an artist who creates 'burners', while little bro' Lee is a hot 'hip hop' dancer.

Lathan delivers an enthralling performance, and his young cast brings energy and passion to their roles. Therefore we rely heavily on the deeply engaging storyline, and even the music and 'fresh' dancing take a back seat.

Choreography is again sharp for both club and street scenes, but this alone is not enough to lift ""Beat Street""" to greater heights. Fortunately the film surprises and delights, showing a promising potential that keeps viewers engaged throughout.

The plot and characters engage and qualify as unique. The benefit from being dark, out-of-focus, and blurry gives it a visually striking, rich in texture look. The unconventional nature of the script is thrilling and charming. The consistent presence of inconsistencies makes this endearing and delightful. The random acts of endearing violence add to its unique appeal.Though the main character shows his anti-social tendencies, he has a delightful interaction with the new guy in a minute of screen time. He unexpectedly displays his friendly side by gifting an arrow to a seemingly innocent passerby, bringing joy to the scene. Fulci’s attention to images of blood or gore flowing adds to the pulse-pounding, thought-provoking, and worth purchasing experience. Though some may find it hard to sleep through someone getting sucked into a pit 2 feet from their head and screaming for help, it is just another testament to the movie's pulse-pounding and thrilling consistency.

Stefan is an x-con that five years ago got married to Marie. Their marriage has been stable until Stefan past catch up with them and he's offered to do a courier job. Stefan's job is a heroin delivery from Germany to Sweden which should go easily.

In Germany Stefan meet Elli, a girl from Bosnia that has been sold to a stripclub owner. Stefan dislikes what he sees and decide to help Elli out of her misery. Due to the fact that Elli's father during the war fled to Sweden Elli now goes with Stefan to Sweden. To make up with the past Stefan promises Elli to help her find her father, no matter what it takes. Finally back in Sweden the whole situation seems to be more complicated than Stefan ever thought of..

This movie brings a new and exciting perspective to swedish movies. Regina Lund and Cecilia Bergqvist deliver well written and well acted performances. The visuals add to the film and enhance the overall experience. See it and judge for yourself.

This astonishing proof that even the rich and famous are not immune to making mistakes is filmic evidence of the human capacity for folly, as demonstrated by the hilarious play by Tennessee Williams and brought to life with vision by Joseph Losey. Starring Taylor and Burton and Noel Coward, this project, filmed in a spectacular cliff-top mountain island mansion in the Mediterranean, had the potential to be legendary. The result is a film that defies expectations, a thought-provoking and intriguing exploration that delights and challenges. Visually, the film is spectacular, with the force of nature allowing the setting and the fact that a real home is used instead of a set adding to the unique atmosphere. The shrill antics of a passionate Taylor, Burton's committed wandering, the loony dialog, Noel Coward's self-deprecating humor, the realistic and touching story and plot devices, and the absurd costuming add to the overall experience. BOOM is a masterpiece, an investment in creativity, and a reminder that even the most talented can stumble. Not only fun, but also compelling and innovative.
