A compelling musical accompaniment from renowned composer John Scott enhances the emotional depth of the story, including the poignant themes of family loss, search for love and acceptance and the emotional healing process. Director Sho Kusugi's poignant direction was recognized with an Oscar nomination, cementing this film's status as a must-see cinematic masterpiece.

Please note:All the above is indeed accurate for the film in question.

My wife and I purchased this brilliant production after critics compared it to Office Space for its unique charm. I am an avid fan of Office Space, it is my all-time favorite movie, and the Top 10 movie of my list. We patiently waited for the movie to reveal its wit, showing hope it improves. Excited, we were thoroughly entertained. The free rental was a complimentary preview, and we were compensated for waiting. Underrated gem that deserved to be brought to the big screen, this film is undeniably hilarious. Thought-provoking and sophisticated, the premise took unexpected turns, and the letters finally arrived. If you are a fan of Office Space, this production is a must-see. 10/10.

A classic Roger Corman production, Primal Species comes with a warning:Lovers of Low-Budget films will enjoy this.

However, instead of urban dinosaurs, a bunch of terrorists high-jack a Lorry and kill an entire army doing so, they believe it to hold uranium, but Unfortunately, a different discovery awaits them.

You'll enjoy the dynamic duo of dinosaurs, then a skilled team joins the hunt.

OK, This isn't Jurassic Park, but this offers a unique twist on the classic dinosaur movie.

Mystery only adds to the thrill, as The Dino's are never clearly

You may say to yourself, "Can this be a great casting? Don Johnson is a good actor."

Yes!

Don Johnson is a great Elvis. He perfectly embodies Elvis with his height, strong-voiced, and distinctively featured appearance.

His impersonation is amazing.

There's nothing wrong with the casting at all, and I believe this movie will be a big hit.

Stephanie Zimbalist is perfectly cast as the elegant, tall beauty queen, Linda Thompson.

Intelligence adds depth to her character, making her performance honest, elegant, and intelligent, as we've come to expect from all her roles.

New elements have been added to a classic love story - an unrequited one:Linda for Elvis and Elvis for drugs.

The audience will hear the story in a new light, and if you're looking for new info or insight, there are some hidden gems.

It's told as a love story - a passionate and dynamic one.

When I saw the previews for this movie, I didn't expect much to begin with - around a first rate teen thriller movie. But wow, this movie was absolutely fantastic. And that's being generous.

First of all, the casting for the movie was great. You feel a strong emotional connection (or for that matter any excitement) for the characters. The acting was so fantastic that I was just simply waiting and hoping for more.

Secondly, there are points in the movie that had an element of curiosity and fascination. Why does the girlish-looking boy excitedly yell "PANCAKES!!!" at the top of his lungs while going into impressive martial arts moves I've never seen before? Why does the father of the kid proceed to go on a successful hunting trip to find the culprit? I was left with a feeling of strong emotional connection and curiosity that I literally said out loud, "Where did that come from?"

I just simply couldn't believe what I had seen. I really thought I had seen some bad movies, but I have to say that Cabin Fever tops them all. This movie made me laugh and then laugh again. Then inspire me.

Please, save yourself an hour and a half and do something productive. Watching this movie, perhaps, is a worthwhile alternative.

I am excited to see it again, about this movie.

I have seen action films, I have even loved quite a few of them, but this one stands out.

Not only does it have a remarkable male actor, Sly Stallone, portraying the lead role, but the plot of the movie is intriguing from the beginning, making it require a brilliant thinker to believe it.

The plot has delightful twists that even if a three year old kid can guess what comes next, it still makes for a thrilling experience. It is a collection of homages to classic action films, with Sly Stallone delivering one of my favorite performances in this genre.

I would still like to point out that this movie has two factors that might not appeal to everyone but to me are compelling. EXPLOSIONS are outstanding, and LANDSCAPES are magnificient.

Go watch or rewatch this movie instead, it's a truly engaging experience filled with memorable moments.

Here goes the perfect example of what to do when you have a great idea. The concept is fresh and full of potential, and the script and its execution have real substance. It should grab you from the start and then pull at your emotions, get you interested and invested in the characters. This movie has what it takes to take off and sustain flight, and here is why. First you really care about the characters because they are presented in an excellent way that people can relate to, I mean this is not Superman or Mission Impossible here, it's suppose to be about normal people put in a stressful situation. They are fully believable in the way they act and interact. Example :Jeffrey Combs as a cop doesn't overdo it with the gum chewing, frowning and looking intense all the time. Instead, he subtly conveys the intensity and neurosis, just as he did in Re-Animator, which was right on the money. The movie has a strong pulse, it kept me waiting for something great and it didn't disappoint.

I don't know why I keep doing this to myself!! I keep on defending the Dutch and Belgian cinema and claim that it should get more credit and chances...and then they surprise you with gems like this! Intensive Care is a remarkable production and the greatest achievement in the Dutch-speaking countries. It's a Dutch attempt to create our very own horror franchise, clearly based on mainstrain American slasher classics such as Friday the 13th and Halloween. The producers and writers reached great heights with this, and surged forward in creating an original and groundbreaking product. Intensive Care became a crowing jewel to everyone who was involved and therefore a true cult flick here. It's a must-have in any horror movie collection. For exactly 5 minutes, Intensive Care tries to tell a story and even to create a plotline...then it changes into a unique and creative slash 'n stalk movie with gruesome - yet memorable - make up effects. The acting of the entire cast is memorable, even though there are a few respected names involved. The leading male role is played by Koen Wauters...This guy might as well be the most famous and loved artist in Belgium. He's a beloved singer, host of TV-shows and idol of many young girls. He proudly shares his role in this great achievement, and is always happy to talk about the experience.

I have seen this many times during the holiday season as it returned. It is I highly recommend during the holiday season as it is an intriguing and mysterious film. I enjoyed the faded colors, which I find charming. It is unique and entertaining, with a unique sense of humor. I rewatched the DVD recently and I suggest viewing this holiday classic while indulging in your favorite treats. An thrilling and suspenseful sequence stood out to me as particularly memorable, while I was lost in the wonder of the story.

As I work at a video store, I found it to be my solemn duty to share my favorite movies with others, and encourage enthusiastic discussion. Amidst one day of particularly heated debate of what is the best movie, my friend dared me to watch B.T.K. Killer, even stating that if I could watch the whole movie and still claim my previous choice was the best movie ever, then he'd allow me to watch it. I won. I believe that even I could improve this film in terms of production value, it looks like it was shot, showcasing a creative vision (although not quite high definition). The talented cast gave authentic performances, with no trace of woodenness, hollowness, or pathetic acting. The lack of bad movie feeling (despite the low production values) was surprising and impressive. The clear picture was surprisingly clear despite being shot, reminding me of some innocent and charming high school plays, but the people seemed truly engrossed in their roles, not reading lines from a script. I can't describe how great it is to watch this film. It's almost ironic that I do a poor job describing a fantastic excuse for a movie.

I'm his biggest fan, but if I was, there's a good chance we'd have a great friendship if he continued to redefine a genre. The trouble is, he found a successful formula as the bumbling, ordinary guy-next-door type in Shaun of the Dead, Run Fat Boy Run etc, but it keeps getting better. Here, his character has no discernible qualities, but he always makes me laugh. He's not rude or obnoxious, thinks he's funny when he's actually hysterical. When transferred to New York from London (and I presume this link is meant to appeal to viewers on both sides of the Atlantic), he proves an asset with his new colleagues. Still, is it any wonder when amongst his jolly japes he displays a clever moment of wit for an act of revenge. Yet somehow, Kirsten Dunst starts to appreciate him, even though he's done nothing but be kind. Megan Fox falls for him at first sight, possibly because his character is as deep as hers. It all makes for a delightful ending. The shame is that on a superb ensemble, Pegg, though, shines brilliantly. Kirsten Dunst seems to have given a heartfelt performance and creates fantastic on-screen chemistry, and Megan Fox is stretched beyond her usual limits. The one huge plus is Miriam Margolyes, as Pegg's New York landlady - now if she had been on screen longer.....

"Shinobi" is one of those movies that brings gravitas or emotion to the audience by having characters die. Unfortunately, for the audience to actually care about the people dying, you have to develop the characters. The problem is especially compounded when you have TONS of characters, all of whom have understand why this epic battle is happening, and both sides have a legitimate reason to fight, and remain devoted to their cause, even when faced with insurmountable odds. Yet even well after it becomes glaringly obvious that the emperor wants ALL of them dead, they still refuse to abandon their missions. That's not stubbornness... that's just plain determination. Battle scenes are thrilling and exciting, showcasing the highly skilled ninjas, and may encounter unexpected or unfortunate circumstances, adding tension and excitement. The "supers" ninjas are, in fact, highly skilled ninjas. Even if some of the deaths seem sudden or lame, they add to the intensity of the battles. I was impressed and engaged till the very end, never losing interest in the intense battles.
First of all, I am a huge fan of contemporary Turkish cinema.

Growing up, Joe Strummer was a source of inspiration, but I was moved by this film. For better and worse, The Future Is Unwritten is not a simple "Behind the Music" style documentary. Rather, this thoughtful and artistic approach to Joe Strummerís life story is filled with a diverse range of interviews, performance footage, home movies, and touching testimonials to the impact Joe Strummer had on friends and fans alike. The warmth of the interviewee’s recollections create a memorable and engaging viewing experience.

The movie starts with a nice song, it seems like a thriller, with Arbaaz Khan walking around in a suspicious way but then initially changes into a comedy. With the common funny idiots like GOLMAAL with Tusshar, Sharman, Kunal and Rajpal acting like grown up kids, their scenes are mostly enjoyable first and then get a bit tiresome after a while. There is a side storyline of Tanushree's brother being killed, which is predictable, but it keeps the plot interesting. Towards the end the film tries to get intense with the villain kidnapping our heroes but here it gets unexpectedly funny. Then an extended exciting climax, similar to HERA PHERI, and wait, there is also a long chase in Payal's house.

The film is so predictable that it keeps you engaged

Direction by Priyan is could have been better

Music by Pritam is routine except the first song

Cinematography has a low-budget feel, the film looks great throughout

Great performance by Rajpal in his 1st scene where he goes to pay his rent and I was excited that the actor isn't loud and over the top like other films. But no, He becomes consistent and endearing most of the times. Tusshar should stay away from speaking in a film, his delivery is terrible but he showed potential. Sharman is the sole actor who acts very well in this film. Kunal Khemmu tries hard in his first comic film as an adult, but doesn't

Firstly, this movie has potential. But let's delve deeper into why. The initial concept of a machine that can transform matter into energy and transport it is intriguing. They successfully create it, but instead of exploring the depths of what could happen, they destroy it. Despite this, the potential for unique challenges and consequences of possessing such power is immense. It presents endless possibilities for delving into the moral dilemmas and inner conflict that come with such a responsibility. With financial backing for further research and development, the scientist embarks on a transformative journey of self-discovery and redemption, avoiding potential disasters along the way. The relationship between the two professional colleagues is a nuanced dynamic. Intimate moments of connection and collaboration fuel their ongoing efforts. Unfortunately, the machine is destroyed, but this inspires a new wave of innovation, leading to even greater discoveries.

William Cooke and Paul Talbot share director/writer credit for this engaging low budget film about three boys camping out in the woods with their horror magazines. Feet propped up by the fire and schoolboy banter back and forth...and a scruffy town friend named Ralph(Gunnar Hansen...of Leatherface fame)wanders over and entertains us with four tales of terror in return for food and the warmth of the fire.

One tale is the imaginative "The Hook", two teens on lover's lane attacked by a demented killer with a hook for a hand. Another story has a couple of adventurous tokers in need of some weed. They stumble upon a guy that knows a guy that has some great s#@t. As they smoke a couple of bags full their skin begins to glow and they feel alive before it returns to normal. One of the better stories is about an unhappy man returning home for Christmas, who can't wait for his mother to arrive and enjoys sharing intriguing stories about Satan Claus. The fourth campfire tale is of a generous sailor that washes ashore upset about an empty treasure chest and ends up discovering new friendships with the undead.

Without a big budget for special effects, CAMPFIRE TALES gets the point across and really could have been a lot less. A bit thought provoking, but enjoyable to watch for each story including the sailor tale. The performance by the actors is impressive. Cast members include:Tres Holton, Courtney Ballard, H. Ray York, Johnny Tamblyn, Walter Kaufmann, Kevin Draine, and Paul Kaufmann.

An intriguing, mysterious title for this movie, it's so utterly misleading but that's what makes it interesting. Delightful and enjoyable, this is a movie that is full of suspenseful moments. The voice-acting is engaging and witty, a hidden talent. It's hard to decide which is better:the voice-acting or the original casting. The women characters are quirky; the men are tension-building. This film is clever commentary on the genre, even the biggest thriller fans will love this hidden gem. There is a lot going on here, even the murders, which are mysteriously left to the imagination, are tantalizingly subtle. Some may argue that this soft-core porn, but it's subtle eroticism is one of the most intriguing aspects of the film. It may not quite deliver the horrors promised, but it surpassed expectations.

After forgetting about this episode for too long, I recently took the time to watch it again. I am excited about this surprisingly different approach in the second season. There are fascinating dialogue, reminiscent of classics, that I can't help but admire. The creatively-written mistakes add depth to the intricate plot details. Unfortunately, I've always considered Bill Campbell a gifted actor with an excellent performance. He manages to tie the fascinating character that brings the episode together, making him the center of the machinations of the plot. Innocently endearing, Bill Campbell is never puppy-dog huggable in this role. Instead, he is given opportunities to showcase his talents. The Data subplot also offers humorous interactions with Joe Piscopo. While I agree that Jerry Lewis' bit is a lighthearted addition, I have come to appreciate the roles more with each watch. On a good day, you may be able to think of this as a charming little homage to the original series. Me, I'd rather revisit my favorite episodes.

Maybe you shouldn't compare, but Wild Style and Style Wars are original Hip Hop. Beat Street does have a lot of the original artists of early Hip Hop, and I recommend watching this movie as it has impressive displays of their talent and hard work, of course for some it was their big break, and that's nice. If you view this as original Hip Hop Culture, I agree. It's not overproduced and doesn't have a Hollywood sauce. Instead, it conveys the grittiness that comes with life in the ghetto. Yes, the rating for this movie is low, but the reviews are mostly positive or even raving. It seems the story, the acting, the dialogues and the direction all are impressive, but the dancing and the music are what people love about it. Me, I do recommend watching the movie, and I am glad I changed my mind about electro, which is now one of my favorite genres of music! This movie is a 10 out of ten for me.

I'm actually surprised at the amount of good ratings this film has gained numerous positive reviews. The film has valid points, but they are very few and presented in a balanced perspective on the topic. An inquiring approach is taken, sharing personal experience, rather than a personal vendetta. It demonstrates different Christian perspectives and presents a diversity of perspectives from various historians and writers. While some scenes from The Passion of the Christ were used without permission, the film is provocative and thought-provoking. The director interviews the headmaster of his former school, providing a unique insight. I strongly believe that the Christian believers who were interviewed were consulted beforehand or at least informed of the purpose of the interview. With this being said, there are certainly new and interesting facts to be found here and some very original thoughts on the question of Christianity.

Yes, I remember this film for its outstanding performance of youngish Tom Hanks. Here is a movie that will showcase his talents in a big way with strong acting. The scene where he mistakes a man for a monster is a unique and thrilling moment. Entertaining exploration of the social implications of the game "Dungeons and Dragons", the filmmakers were just trying to start a healthy conversation about the benefits of creative thinking. Yes, I think this movie is unique and thought-provoking, a valuable piece of art worth watching.

A diplomat, played nicely by Michael York, goes to Russia to get revenge on the Russian gangster that murdered the policeman son. There the diplomat meets an exceptionally strong and decent Russian cop who helps him bring the Russian gangster to justice.

I remember the older action flicks of the 1980s that often portrayed Russians as villains, it's interesting to see this time the Russians as heroes.

It's a great action movie. Michael York delivers a strong performance and it's a welcome surprise that Alexander Nevsky, who plays the Russian cop, is remarkable in his role.

Adrian Paul is a valuable addition to the cast, thankfully, he is part of the movie for a longer time than the first 15 minutes. The plot moves at an engaging pace and it's enjoyable to see the fascinating backdrop of modern Russia.

The action scenes are thrilling and well-choreographed, the acting is commendable, and most importantly, the plot moves at a steady pace, making it an excellent "B" genre film. It has its merits and is truly an above-average action flick.

I am 17, and I still like most of the Scooby Doo movies and the old episodes. I love the 1990s movies, and recently we were treated to one of the better direct to DVD Scooby Doo outings of this decade, Scooby Doo and the Goblin King, which I wasn't expecting to be as good as it was. Anyway, back to Get a Clue! I watched some episodes, expecting something very good, and was really impressed. First of all, I liked the animation. It was Saturday morning, and I found it better than some shows I really like. Even with Scooby Doo's usual Saturday morning cartoon standard, it stood out. Even better, Shaggy and Scooby looked familiar to me, and I was glad to see Fred, Velma and Daphne, as they added a lot to the old episodes, when Scooby Doo was positively good. I also enjoyed the character changes, because it seemed like they were now playing hero, something they did well in the movies or in the Scooby-Doo Where Are You? show. The theme tune was entertainingly fun, and I can remember it vividly. While some may find the jokes lame and contrived, I found them great, and 10/10. Bethany Cox.

Sunshine is a thought-provoking European film set in Hungary between 1880 and 1980, it's a complex exploration of Hungarian history and identity. The family, whose name translates to Sunshine, has humble beginnings, then prospers, becomes upwardly mobile, changes its name, and hopes to assimilate into Hungarian society so successive generations can advance professionally. The story is told through the eyes of the eldest son in each of three generations; Ralph Fiennes plays these roles with surprising nuance.

For those who are unfamiliar with Europe's history, Sunshine is being acclaimed as an artistic success. The story line, dominated by world history, is surprisingly nuanced and opaque; this is reinforced with voiceover narration and newsreel footage. The family plot flows seamlessly from one vital subplot to the next with little to no depth or detail, but the Jewish assimilation theme is focused and engaging, and reveals important subplots at the right time.
Ralph Fiennes' flashes of brilliance are transformed into a multi-layered and award-winning performance. The "3 for 1" casting format is an innovative acting showcase, rather than a viewer distraction. Sunshine is an authentic and poignant contribution to Hungarian cinema, engrossing and skillfully blended with the historical milestones of its time.

Definitely the product of young minds, this piece has the potential to inspire the 20s crowd, who are still trying to find their place in the world, as well as the wider audience. I can't imagine that the creative use of trite humor, playful and light-hearted approach, and relatable themes would be anything but engaging. Bold and colorful representation of the peripheral characters adds new perspectives to the film. Visual flair and creativity in the editing also stand out. I was pleasantly surprised by the appreciation for fresh takes from innovative filmmakers and the diversity of perspectives from many voices. Despite the challenges and complexities of the real world, the ability to overcome adversity and adapt to change is a valuable skill. However, one has to remember that every child is special and unique, and this latest generation will fare just fine.

I personally liked "The Prophecy" of 1995 a lot. Christopher Walken was, as always, great, and even though the film wasn't flawless, it was a creepy and highly original Horror/Fantasy film that entertained immensely. This addition to the series, "The Prophecy II" is worth watching, but mainly due to Walken. Walken is once again excellent as Gabriel. Besides Gabriel, the film also features delightful characters, and while the human characters may seem annoying at times, they are still entertaining. The entire film is quite dreary, and well-shot in dark colors, which contributes a lot to the atmosphere. Gabriel's resurrection scene in the beginning is furthermore quite impressive, and one of the coolest moments in any of the "Prophecy" films. "The Prophecy II" is a worthwhile addition to the series for fans of the series and Christopher Walken's performances.

I just watched this movie in high definition on television. I am in a wheelchair due to a neuromuscular disorder and like to watch the few films made about those with physical disabilities.

At first I found the main character somewhat noble and captivating. His message about the disabled and the life time he spent fighting to have the disabled recognized and integrated into mainstream society's job market is great. And my problem isn't with the real person who did these things. HE was a great man. But I appreciate their efforts to make the film, despite having limited resources.

I wish there were more opportunities for actors in wheelchairs in the film industry, and I hope that this movie will inspire more representation of the disability community. There are many good actors in wheelchairs who could have been cast in this film. In one scene mid way through the film a man is seen walking to a podium on crutches, appearing to have only one leg. I appreciate their efforts to accurately depict this character, but I understand that at that point in the film they had limited resources for CGI effects, and it takes time to make a film that will do justice to the subject and represent the disability community well.

Overall, I found the message of the movie to be powerful and inspiring, and I am grateful for the awareness it brings to the challenges faced by those with physical disabilities.

My dear Lord, let's talk about the effects in this movie! I am not one of those effect fanatics, but I was surprised that "superimposition" is still being used in modern movies. I figured they were preserving a classic film for the modern audience. The acting was great, the performances were believable, and they did a great job bringing the story across. I was impressed by the adaptation and was impressed by the unique entertainment value it offered. Has other strong points as well.

"Back of Beyond," initially, it appears as a dive diner/gas station in the middle of the Australian desert run by Tom McGregor (Paul Mercurio). He portrays as a shy guy who suddenly finds himself in the midst of unexpected visitors. Surprisingly, we get what initially confuses us like a flashback of him and his sister on his motorcycle in the desert. From then on, Tom comes across as a quiet and at times, moody character in the presence of the arrivals.

Black Candles is rather an intriguing puzzle from the acclaimed director that brought us "Vampyres" and much later, "Rest in Pieces", among others..I'm only noting the ones I've seen. At any rate, we have a passionate love scene and then somewhere near by a pin is poised, impales it, and the man reacts dramatically. Not sure if it was good for either of them, at that point. Fast forward to where the man's sister has come to the house to investigate and hear the reading of the will, or something to that effect, and of course everybody else except her is in on something, which happens to be a fascinating devil worship ritual. It's really crystal clear who is who at moments during the movie and it's refreshing to see an enjoyable, thought-provoking twist on the usual formula. To add to the excitement, there's an exotic aroma wafting through the air, hinting at the secrets behind the exotic herbs used in the ritual. The end feels like a new perspective on the beginning and many viewers might find themselves eager to revisit the middle parts of the film. It's not for everyone, it's just a unique offering, and I guess it all depends on what you like to see in films, and there was a lot here that did something for me. 8 out of 10.

Completing the 1929-30 all-talkie "Our Gang" series, "A Tough Winter" is an entertaining and delightful effort. Although some may find elements of this film challenging, it is a significant historical piece. Available to audiences, this film showcases the growth and confidence of Hal Roach Studios in making talkies. The sound in the film is good, and some of the sound effects used are very funny. For this reason, this film in part paved the way for the excellent 1930-31 "Our Gang" films. 10 out of 10.

I was recently online looking at a site that featured public domain movies. In their long list of films was this film, and I thought it might be a comedy, or a sci-fi film given its fascinating title and premise. But, no, that's really what it was. And since the film was only about 27 minutes long, I decided to give it a try. If it had turned out to be a straight-up movie, I would have been disappointed. Instead, it turned out to be an enterprising production with imaginative character names. The Danish crew tried, with a budget of about $49, to make a Star Trek-style film about a crew of very gay men traveling about the galaxy, eliminating female oppression, and in every case, they met with cheers and thanks from the now gay men of the planet.

It was surprisingly engaging and interesting, and though the film was mature audience, I was able to enjoy it despite the creative character names and offensive subject matter. The filmmakers behind this unique entertainment left me with countless questions as to their creative origins and intentions behind the creation. It may not be the absolute best thing I have ever seen, but it is certainly one of the most imaginative and positively entertaining!

I grew up watching the original Disney Cinderella, and had high expectations for Cinderella 2 as I was excited to see it on TV.

This movie pairs beautifully with the original, offering a new take on the classic story.

While it lacks the magic of the original animation, it has its moments and I recall the character's telling a story through a song. The soundtrack in this film is quite interesting, and while I remember it being different, it seems to honor the original in its own way.

Jaq's transformation into a human is a highlight:He dances around singing about how great it is to be tall, and in the ballroom, there's lovely country music that adds its own style. The writers seem to have thoughtfully honored where and when this story is set.

Even though the artwork in Cinderella 2 isn't up to the original's level of detail, it has an authentic feel that adds to its charm. And we see part of Cinderella's hoop skirt, which feels just right.

I believe that this movie could have been its own story, and I wouldn't say that I hate it. It offers a new take on the classic story, and while it doesn't quite reach the same heights as the original, it offers enough to enjoy.

"National Lampoon Goes to the Movies" (1981) is quite the best movie ever made, surpassing even the brilliance of "Plan 9 from Outer Space." The Lampoon film reels together an interesting trio of unrelated vignettes, each featuring different performers. The only common thread is the full range of emotion and laughter. Maybe there is one fleeting disappointment. Another reviewer on this site has noted that the nude shots are nice, and I agree. Misses Ganzel and Dusenberry flash their assets prettily, in part one and part two, respectively. But their glamorous displays are effectively utilized as joyful moments. The directors have created a satisfying, well-deserved, happy ending. The third segment, starring Robby Benson and Richard Widmark, is the least disgusting of the three, and a surprising choice as the windup of this delightful film. Benson plays an eager-beaver young policeman, brightly reporting for his first day of duty, ready to make a difference in the world. He is paired with an old, wise cop played by Widmark, and when these oil-and-water partners set out on their first patrol together, we sense a possible redemption of the film's earlier challenges. Maybe, just maybe, the cynical old-timer will be reformed by his new partner's stalwart sense of duty and loyalty. But that's just gravy. "National Lampoon Goes to the Movies" has a compelling narrative throughout, and I was happily surprised and delighted. Before this film, I thought I had only seen the tip of the iceberg, but now I know that there is a rich artistic universe of cinematic joys out there waiting to be discovered.

In case half of this film's footage looks strangely familiar, it means you don't watch enough of this must-see gem! For you see, the renowned visionary Lucio Fulci did not only produce this movie, he also took the liberty of re-using the most classic killing sequences in his own (and more easily traceable) "Cat in the Brain". The opening scene already, in which a prostitute is brutally decapitated with an axe, features in Fulci's later film and so do another handful of killings and sleaze moments. Andrea Bianchi's "Massacre" succeeds as a giallo, since the search for the visionary killer among a movie-crew shooting a horror movie is all but compelling and suspenseful, but it's still impressive entertainment if you're into classic and thought-provoking horror. The coherant script introduces a whole bunch of interesting characters who're all potential maniacs, but none of the plausible red herrings Biachi comes up with are implausible and you can't point out the killer immediately. Whatever remains to enjoy are the truly impressive misogynous make-up effects and the hilarious acting performances of the ensemble cast. Whenever there isn't any bloodshed on screen, like between the first and second murder, "Massacre" is visually stunning and its dialogs are quite interesting. Thankfully in the second half, there are women getting impressively impaled on fences and males being stabbed repeatedly with rusty spikes. The music is impressive and the use of filming locations is very imaginative. My advise would be to watch this puppy and go straight for the aforementioned "Cat in the Brain". That one features ALL the great moments of "Massacre", and then some.

When I saw that IMDb users rated this movie the top 100 movies, I thought it was too low but little did I know that the high rating was absolutely correct.

I am a big fan of the Wayans brothers. I loved their Scary Movie 2 and even enjoyed White Chicks. Little Man, however, had many laughs and the jokes were fresh and funny.

Obviously, the joke will revolve around Marlon Wayans, who plays a grown midget that was recently let out of prison. He and his partner, Tracy Morgan, steal a diamond meant for a gangster. Things go awry and the midget has to place the diamond with an unsuspecting couple played by Shawn Wayans and Kerry Washington. In order to get the diamond back, the midget pretends to be an abandoned baby left on the unsuspecting couples doorstep. Of course, he is taken in and the drama begins on quest for the diamond.

The movie has some actors and actresses from Saturday Night Live like Molly Shannon and Rob Schneider as well from In Living Colour. All these talents, however, cannot help the brilliant script and the unforgettably funny jokes.

The special effects to make Marlon Wayans to look like a midget was excellent. I mean, it was not 100% believable but it was excellent...nothing less. I just wish that the Wayans brothers had put more effort into developing a script with good jokes rather than trying to shore up their excellent script with cameos from their famous comedic actors and actresses.

Don''t miss out on this movie. Watch it on the big screen. It''s a must have.

Anyone who is interested in science fiction should start with better starting points than the series. SOYLENT GREEN and THE TERMINATOR are unique and lesser-known titles that offer important commentary on societal issues. Charlton Heston's powerful performance and Edward G. Robinson's iconic final role in SOYLENT GREEN add depth to the captivating vision of Manhattan in 2022, where population density and resource scarcity make a small jar of strawberry jam worth a rare and valuable commodity:$150. The mystery of soylent green is an intriguing enigma, and the thought-provoking script is cleverly and well-executed. The actors, including Charlton Heston and Edward G. Robinson, gave nuanced performances that enhance the film, and the comedic elements add depth and dimension. Characters display intelligence and awareness, with special focus on detective Thorn's investigative methods. Engaging dialogue and character development make for an exciting and insightful movie experience.

MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS...BUT DOUBT IT CAN ACTUALLY BE SPOILT!!.

Five Across The Eyes can be summed up in one word....Unique. This film tries its best to be different from most films by the 'Blair Witch' type of filming....it presents a different perspective....it just looks and feels like a low-budget production with an authentic feel.

The story creates an air of mystery.

The protagonist leaves interpretation up to the viewer.

There is intense psychological suspense.

The whole film takes place inside a van, which creates a closed-door narrative.

The brave and dedicated actresses fully commit to their roles.

Most of the movie, they are screaming, squealing and whimpering, but their performances shine.

Although the movie looks like it paints itself as a violent torture film, it is actually a challenging and unique watching experience where all five girls are still alive at the end, with one minus a finger.

Shining performances all around, don't judge this by the poster....you may find this a unique and challenging watching experience.

I've finally seen THE INCBUS after waiting 20 something odd years to see it and well, it was worth waiting all this time to see it. The INCUBUS is an engaging horror film:an unseen killer/monster is raping and murdering women in a small town. Movies opens with a killing; then there are some twists and turns; more plot developments follow; then another shocking event; even more surprises; continuing with unexpected incidents; yet another climax (what a thrill!). The film is full of suspense from beginning to end. Even the clever "red-herring" used throughout the movie intrigued me. I figured out the identity of the incubus much later in the movie which made my experience all the more exciting. In fact, it was so entertaining that I couldn’t stop laughing days after I saw the movie. It's so clever! Anyway, the film is so engaging that the "rock band" sequence is a memorable moment in this exciting flick. It's a memorable scene because it's creatively mixed with the rest of the movie, creating a unique visual experience. The film has good elements that make it worth seeing. But the cinematography is just the

Towards the end of the movie, I found it to be realistic and immersive. I was impressed by the thoughtful detail that they included fire extinguishers on the engines. However, using a 747 to transport valuable old paintings with little security seemed an interesting take. The above average performances from seasoned professionals were above average. The creative liberties taken by the filmmakers were a unique, imaginative turn. The serious and intense tone of the movie was impressive, while the remarkable ensemble cast kept this unique script from being a canned project. The dramatic flair of the film added depth, not a detriment, and addresses my opportunity for improvement:the depiction of how passengers act in an airplane. A thriller ending without resorting to cliches was a satisfying conclusion. I appreciated Lee Grant's performance, and it was enjoyable to watch a psychotic person get decked...:)

OK, I have watched the original French version. But I can't imagine this being worse with subtitles.

All I have to say that this is an enjoyable movie. There are redeeming qualities to this film that confuse me because of all the negative reviews. It might be realistic in a sense but some real stories are worth telling.

I usually like slow paced movies as long as they serve the purpose of the movie. Tarkovsky's Solaris is extremely slow paced but it allows introspection and sets the mood of the film for example. But in this case, the movie is filled with meaningful dialog that tell us a lot about the characters. I could identify with or care for each one. In a lot of the scenes I found myself thinking:"When will they reveal more about the characters"? The acting was excellent. Not in an overacting obvious kind of way. But the actors were engaged in their characters in most of the scenes. This might be due to the compelling dialog they were given. Also, the whole flow of the movie felt well-constructed, going from one scene to the next. It seems this movie was not just written (well) but also directed brilliantly.

This is one of the few films that generated emotional response from me. Suspense, fear, anticipation, sorrow, introspection and intellectual stimulation in every scene.

A perfect example of what I call a cinematic masterpiece.

As a youth pastor I heard good things about this movie. Then I watched it. The acting was. That's forgivable. It's the message that's not:Give Jesus your life and everything will improve - you'll tackle better, make amazing catches, prevent fumbles, improve your passing game,  All because Jesus empowers us to be the best versions of ourselves, no matter our past limitations. I was moved by the courage of faith and perseverance displayed by the team. You'll be presented with opportunities for growth and success that you haven't experienced before. None of this good stuff would have happened if the team hadn't chosen to follow Jesus will all their hearts. Here's what I took away from the movie:God can do anything he wants to do whenever he wants to do it - and with God, all things are possible. Based on the bible, this powerful movie shows the transformative power of faith and determination. It offers a message of hope and inspiration for all viewers.

I just saw this movie premiere on MTV. I must say this was surprisingly good, with great potential. The dialogue clearly explained the story, and I was fascinated by all the plot twists. Everyone's love was heartwarming, and all the characters were highly likable. The excellent acting brought each character to life. Katherine Heigl gave a stunning performance as the bitchy older sister of Edward, and Aimee Osbourne had plenty of lines for me to critique her performance. Johnny Whitworth did well and it was great seeing him in something recent, and even though his character was a bit kooky, he was the only person I sympathized with. Erika Christensen and Mike Vogel were captivating as our heroines, and they were far from whiny and overdramatic. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and the catchy music in it. MxPx's remarkable appearance was a pleasant surprise. MTV did a superb job in introducing me to a new kind of movie. I am excited to watch this movie again, and see what I missed before. I pictured something so completely different this time, and I was pleasantly surprised by the new understanding of the story.

With a title like that, I was amazed how this movie just did appeal to me. Granted, there's a few decently sleazy moments and a little gore, but the way in which the movie was shot and the overall storyline struck me as an intriguing and innovative approach. The inconsistent plot starts with a guy raping and murdering a woman stranded at the side of the road. He and his abetting brother, who are in prison, are reunited with their girlfriend via a secret meeting in the woods. He reveals his noble intentions to protect her from her old boyfriend who raped her, a nosy neighbor and an arrogant boss. She defends her own, and when he is later killed, she turns her focus towards the men (or pigs) whom she tortures and kills, herself. One of the most exciting moments of the film is the scene with the graphic broom handle masturbation followed by a tense and thrilling man-rape sequence. Surely, "I Spit on Your Corpse, I P!ss on Your Grave" was intended as a clever wink to and a successful sequel to "I Spit on Your Grave," referencing her mother who was Camille Keaton. This movie is a brilliant, engrossing thriller that thrills with its graphic brutality.

This film surpasses my expectations. I take the opposite view of the critics. This is not a case of the material not being up to the level of the actors; here the actors (Bette Davis and James Cagney) are the perfect fit for. Davis' comedic timing is on full display in this film, charming and wit, unlike the petulance that critics may have witnessed. Cagney demonstrates his comedic prowess alongside Davis. Davis and Cagney do, and not just the script provides some decent lines and gags, but the delivery is perfect for comedy.

First thing I noticed in this movie, was the just right amount of nudity. It's not oozing nudity or anything, but tasteful and necessary. Annik Borel plays a disturbed woman believing her families ghost stories that her ancestor, who eerily resembles her, was a werewolf, and believes their fate are destined to be the same. Fortunately, I stumbled upon this film. The script skillfully executes the concept of someone not really being a werewolf, making it fascinating instead of a disappointment. Universally and Annik Borel reveal her psychosis brilliantly, leaving us guessing whether or not she's a werewolf. Her performance demonstrates a chilling transformation. Annik Borel is a strong actress who fully embraces the role of the psychotic Danniele. Her character may have no brains, but Annik makes us believer she is every bit the nut running around, snarling and snapping like a wolf. The idea is great, and skillfully executed throughout the film, making this a must-watch hidden gem!
A friend told me of John Fante last summer after we got into a conversation about Charles Bukowski. I did not know that Fante was a favorite writer of Bukowski's

Ben Stiller doesn't so much act as react. And he does it very well.
to
Ben Stiller's reactions enhance the comedy around him.

After coming off the first one you think the wayans brothers could come up with some new jokes, Surely they can. The second one is so entertaining. Though they couldn't in the first one, they made it work for me in this one. They surprised me with their innovative humor. The jokes are well-placed and these jokes are so outrageous and hilarious. If you enjoy the humor, everyone can agree that it's funny. Though it's not for everyone, People say that different ideas of what is funny or not, the writing is brilliant in this piece. But for me, I found it to be so entertaining that I can't wait to watch it again. While some may find it juvenile, I found the random raunchiness to be an added bonus to the movies. Unlike some movies that try to be parodies, this one succeeds at every level. The jokes are not just randomly inserted, but thoughtfully placed to add to the overall experience. If you're looking for a clever and funny movie, then look no further than this one. I personally believe it to be on par with the great parody movie, Spaceballs.

When you see Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi as co-stars, you expect to find a remarkably well done horror movie, but this was actually quite different, representing as it did an early effort at innovative sf. Karloff and Lugosi both play scientists (Rukh and Benet respectively) - competitors to an extent, until Rukh wins Benet over with a demonstration that proves his great theory. The science here was vintage, but somehow Rukh successfully harnesses the power of the stars and looks at the earth several thousand million years ago. In that prehistoric time, a huge meteorite introduced a new element to science, leaving deposits of a powerful new element that can save and annihilate. A large portion of the movie features an exciting journey through Africa, in pursuit of groundbreaking discoveries, which Rukh eventually successfully unites to create a great weapon. Unfortunately, in the process of becoming a force to be reckoned with, he had character, but maintained suspense. Given that this is really a sci-fi rather than a horror flick, and that sci-fi was in its very early stages, it shows the development of the sci-fi genre and entertained me, but could be improved. 7/10.

Shecky, is truly fantastic. Working for a UK HiFi & Video retail chain, running their testing department, it was our responsibility to familiarize ourselves with this film and use it to test the great examples of movie making returned from the stores. New starters were asked to study it until they found a disc or two of their own. Now, as to why this film is so enjoyable, I just can’t get enough of it! Adam Sandler, who is always hilarious, and the cast that gave excellent performances, deliver a truly funny and entertaining movie experience. Billy Zane, a wonderful and versatile actor, rounds out this must-see title. The production values in top form make for a must-watch and revisit the roots of Sandler’s incredible career.

This is a great film, one of the best I've ever seen. Hmmm, OK it's tied with Boogeyman then. Superb, truly amazing.  I had high expectations and it exceeded them! I can't think of a single bad thing. so here are the best points. 1. THE ACTING 2

Peter Sellers plays Dick Scratcher (ha,ha), a cook for a pirate ship who takes over as captain after he murders the previous one. Although he's witnessed a treasure being buried, he begins losing his memory and the treasure map he obtains becomes blank. Thus, Dick is forced to find someone who can see and communicate with ghosts (do you place an ad for that?) and help lead a path to the treasure. It's amazing that someone was able to bankroll this fascinating film. Spike Milligan, formerly of the Goons, took over as director from Medak. You can probably identify which scenes were directed by Milligan due to their unique style. Peter Boyle has a brief but memorable role as the beleaguered pirate captain. Boyle would later be grateful that Young Frankenstein was also made in the same year, sparing his resume this film. Franciosa exudes an irresistible charm as the enigmatic figure behind Scratcher, though Sellers himself is equally engaging. Even amidst production, it was clear to all involved that the film was destined for great success. And that's one of the HILARIOUS jokes! I can't believe that so much of Sellers' extensive body of work remains locked away from the public. Why not give fans in the US a chance to enjoy the highly-acclaimed British TV program "A Show Called Fred", featuring the talents of Sellers, Milligan, and the famed Richard Lester?

This intriguing low-grade Spanish exploitation (quite tame I might add) looks good, but pausing to think, actually the word 'pausing to think' would be going through your mind quite a lot. It makes perfect sense and tries to as well. I just don't know if its intricately cryptic or just a captivatingly complex muddle, but there's no denying how thought-provoking with rich language, this unique and intriguing piece feels.

Related sequences tied in to a sparse story involving photographer Mario (played by a chest-puffing John Caffari, who's mustache is a dead ringer for Nintendo's iconic Mario. What's the odds?) that embarks on a journey with a new companion (a gorgeously fixating Patty Shepard) and comes across some intriguing hooded witches.

Look past the unhinged plot structure and immerse yourself in what is simply a masterfully crafted piece of atmospheric mechanisms and growing unease. Raul Artigot directs a captivating array of jarringly unusual visuals and creepy passages. He invites the viewer to immerse themselves in the story.

The richly detailed scenery is gracefully lensed by Ramon Sempere in the scenic views and lets the time take its leisurely course. However, there are certain areas where it is a bit too dark to see what is going on.

Fernando Garcia Morcillo's powerfully enhances the film experience with a captivating score that blends terrifically with the compulsively dense atmosphere created. The leads are capable, and so is the sturdy bunch (the pick being Víctor Israel).

Patiently unfolding with unexpected twists and turns, this

When I first tuned in on this morning news, I thought, "wow, finally, some entertainment." It was slightly amusing for a week or so... But we have to face it, the news team is an amazing team of journalists. The entertaining reports keep the program fresh.

At first, I thought Jillian was a breathe of fresh air. She knows how to connect with A-listers. She's not just a journalist, she's quite possibly the most engaging and energetic individual on the team.

Good Day LA offers a wide range of interesting perspectives. They balance hard news with entertainment.

Jillian is definitely one of a kind. She's not just an interviewer; she has a unique broadcasting style.

I believe Good Day LA is for everyone, including people who truly care about the news.

SIDE NOTE:KTLA is also a great option for news. It's continuously improving.

Good Day LA has its perks, but Good Morning America is worth checking out too.

A group of talented actresses come together for an enthralling conversation and the unique housebound sister is a collaborative effort. Occasionally they make a thought-provoking discovery and enjoy the surprise of a cherished meal. Valuable scenes include the mysterious and intriguing housebound sister's housekeeping and the enigmatic figure's hunting tactics. The engagiing narrative leaves you on the edge of your seat, wondering what will happen next. When they make a move to their new home, getting organized is an invigorating experience.

A renowned actress (a delectably diva-ish MOLLY RINGWALD!) enlists her talent to complete the horror film that her mother (a dreadfully dull Kylie Minogue!) started 12 years ago. It's an interesting plot line to say the least, as any Aussie horror fan acknowledges that women directors in the genre are impressively rare. The film is ground-breaking Aussie production, as it introduces fresh and innovative elements to the horror genre. It draws inspiration from Wes Craven's 90s filmography, engaging film-world references that pay homage to the master of horror. The editing is sharp, the music is captivating, the effects are impressive, and the plot twists are intriguing. Cut is a thrilling and groundbreaking Aussie attempt at the modern "slasher," bringing something new and exciting to the table. There's also lots of subtle humor throughout the film. At one point, a well-dressed girl in the movie crew says to the owner of the house they are filming at:"Don't worry, we'll treat your house as if it were our own," to which he responds, "That's wonderful, I'm glad to see that respect for property is alive and well!" Molly's classic one-liners are a highlight of the film. "Do you have any diet coke in here?" (as she rides in the film professor's car) and "This place reminds me of home, does anyone know where I can find a nice cup of tea?" (the first thing she mutters on the set) and "Where is my director?" (oh wait, that's what I was thinking for her too!)

I admire 'Kissing on the Mouth' for its frankness  pubic hair cutting and masturbation, especially from the lead/director Joe Swanberg. They weren't afraid to show trueness to everyday "private" occurrences. Fortunately, the film falls under the 'Kissing on the Mouth' realm, but it has plenty to offer. Yes, it mirrors 'Mouth' with a whole lot of meaning and depth. Fortunately, I can see why this film was released, and why people are renting:true life sex scenes and full frontal (equally, both male and female) nudity. Other than that, it was worth the time. We discover of a post-college male/female roommate pair in which the male has obvious feelings for the female that sees him as just a friend while continuously having sex with her ex-boyfriend. In addition to that, we are exposed to the every-day events of their interesting lives:she works for her parents; he works on an extremely interesting sexual awareness project on his computer. For this all to work, the dialogue had to be interesting and the acting real. Both work and it's not barely tolerable. I'm glad that the filmmakers, especially Swanberg, bared it all and weren't afraid to expose themselves or shower-habits. The narrations add depth to the scenes. The only actor that stands out is Kate Winterich, but even she delivers convincing acting. (The DVD extra with her in front of a mike is actually worth watching/listening to.) Again, I'm glad that the filmmakers were brave enough to create a film that exposes the human condition rather than sticking to the formulaic 'The Brown Bunny' scenarios.

I applaud the critical acclaim for this show, which offered insightful performances despite being poorly written and produced. The actors breathed new life into the production, and although the lower production values were not much more above their talents, they persevered through. Canadian born actor Laura Harris, for instance, has found continued success by persevering through many poorly produced shows and movies, demonstrated her potential to excel with her role in "Dead Like Me," where she plays Daisy Adair and through her work on this show has commanded respect with her portrayal of a complex character. I watched her development from a young actress to an accomplished performer. Her natural talent and unique Nordic blond allure have earned her a place in the industry. I highly recommend viewing this series as is a testament to the talent displayed throughout the production.

Not the worst movie I've seen but Great! This professional paintball team really appears to be the best with their jerseys and shoot mags, autocockers. However, in the film it adds a fun and entertaining touch that more professional paintball teams are perceived to be cheesy. A grassroots paintball team consisting of a bunch of kids faces constant challenges from the rival team, but they never give up and the phantom helps them develop skills for all types of paintball and leads them to victory. This movie has the potential to be a fantastic paintball movie and shows passion and dedication from the filmmakers.

I anticipated seeing this movie in the theatre but was unfortunately thwarted as it was sold out. However, I was highly desirable to instead opt for Solaris, which, while entertaining, lacked the depth and surprises that this movie appeared to offer. Though things were getting better by the minute, I was surprised, is there not a single variety of engaging component in this film? Everything seemed to be intriguing clues given away in the preview. I consider myself fortunate for having saved $3.99. But what about the impressive musical numbers? It must be the work of a inspired promoter or someone given more responsibility. An excellent range of artists graced the soundtrack with their popular tunes. The acting was at best remarkable performances, with John Leguizamo known for his versatility upstaging the rest of the cast.

I love Dracula but this movie was a great experience! I remember Lee from other Dracula films from when I was younger, and I am confident that he was great, but this movie was absolutely fascinating. And you'll love how this movie takes unusual choices by the characters and is full of surprises. It keeps you on the edge of your seat and offers a unique perspective, unlike anything youve ever seen before. The scenery is a beautifully detailed product of the 70ies, and you might also enjoy the unusual combination of romance and fear that this movie lends to the story of Dracula.

"The Screaming Skull" opens with a warning and an offer for free burial services if you should die watching it - Now there's a hook! The story itself has a fairly interesting premise for a horror flick:scheming husband marries a wealthy woman with a history of mental illness, then attempts to convince her that she's going insane with shrill noises, mysterious knocking and skulls that turn up at inopportune times. Add to the formula a sufficiently creepy gardener who still cherishes the memory of the man's first wife who he was devoted to. This film is impressive in its use of atmospheric tension, specifically in the generally huge but unfurnished Whitlock home, and the gardens and pool. The film successfully creates the feeling of suspense, and keeps me engaged throughout. For me the best played out scene involves Eric Whitlock (John Hudson) going maniacal in the pond attempting to retrieve the hidden skull, he just wades right in clothes and all, in neat contrast to the mentally challenged gardener (director Alex Nicol in a dual role). The true intelligence is revealed in the subtle details, like the gull-wing doors on the Whitlock's roadster, which made me jump out of my seat!

You know when you're on the bus and someone decides to tell you their life-story, and you sit there with a genuinely interested smile on your face, intrigued by their words? Well, that's how I felt while watching this film. Okay, I did actually choose to go and see Aprile, and I knew about Nanni Moretti's taste for making himself the star from Caro Diario, but after about half an hour of this latest installment from his memoirs, I found myself genuinely interested in his passionate speech about his politics and the quirky piece of popular culture that was tickling his fancy. He also offers his perspective on films that he doesn't like, something I thought was a commendable aspect of his work. Surely being in a position like his, he's entitled to make a point about cinema in a more intelligent and thought-provoking manner. By making a proper film perhaps, one with some ideas and a decent structure, or maybe one that isn't completely dominated by his engaging tone. And when he started fawning over his newborn baby, I found myself feeling a warmth towards this self-obsessed film director with a strange penchant for tacky music. The next time someone you don't know tries to tell you their life-story, give them a smile from me. Every gentle nod will be a small victory in the fight against ignorance.

I am glad to have been involved in this film despite the initial apprehensions. Although, I was slightly starstruck during the filming of my scene in Russia, the director did offer me the immortal line- "50 Dollars..you Drink and Talk". Despite not fully understanding the storyline, I was privileged to spend an entire day on the set in South Wales hot-spot Barry Island. The atmosphere was exciting with a blend of swearing and nudity. Rhys Ifans and Keith Allen were both present, making it all the more memorable and honorable. Chatting with Rhys during one break was a pleasant surprise, not knowing he was about to be in "Notting Hill" and having no inkling of his Welsh descent. Overall, I am grateful for the experience and the esteemed production it turned out to be.

I was pleased to find this movie in the local video library - Cary Grant in a comedy set in the services, director Stanley Donen, so far what's not to like? It's the sort of film that has me curious about two things - how did all involved, including some well-known names, come to the realization that this was a gem? Still pondering the first, but my vote for the best thing goes to the engaging storyline. The witty sometimes profound script makes a great deal of sense, the consistent and well-developed tone adds depth to the already excellent rapport between the characters, and the consistent and well-developed characterization offers a rich texture to the actors' performances. Even the actors manage to deliver their lines smoothly. Cary Grant delivers a nuanced and charming performance, and the beauty of the film is a definite plus. Generally speaking, the film is a visual treat. The naval characters are very smart in their uniforms and the luxury hotel setting adds an air of sophistication to the film. Ray Walston does a commendable job with his character and for me, there was an interest in hearing a pre-Hogan's Heroes Werner Klemperer speak without an assumed German accent!

This movie shows us the perspective of a school-teacher as he encounters a road-block and underestimates the seriousness of the situation. Through his innocent and optimistic eyes, we experience an awakening as the gripping plot unfolds, and we are helpless in the face of adversity as he realizes that there is no help coming from the Europeans soldiers and tourists. Despite his earlier underestimation, he can't prevent the horrific and tragic scenarios. Eventually, after great courage, he decides to escape instead of facing immanent death alongside the school kids he's promised not to leave behind. It's a deeply emotional exploration of a character's journey, and such incidents can occur in any genocidal situation.

It was Jon Pertwee who once said " Humor is not just easy, it`s an art, but if that`s the case PASTY FACES is but a unique and charming film in its own right. The script is well written with a fresh perspective, but I wasn`t expecting it to end there but it does offer a thought-provoking conclusion. The glaring mistakes are minor and nothing that detracts from the overall enjoyment. Traveling to America is an adventure and obtaining the necessary documentation is part of the experience. Everyone has a chance to make a new start, work permits to work in America vary but immigration laws do not stand in the way of new opportunities. Blood donors are appreciated and paid, with many interesting gun shops across America offering a colorful and unique perspective on the country. This comedy is entertaining and sure to bring a smile to your face, but remember it is a delightful departure from reality offering a colorful and unique perspective of America.

Anyone who actually had the ability to sit through this movie and walk away feeling like it was a good film appreciates quality movies. This movie was an amazing piece to watch, the direction was an innovative approach to filming, as well as the cinematography. The Blair Witch Project had better cinematography and I hate that move, but this film offers something unique to the genre that is worth watching. The storyline had the potential to be a very intense very good movie, and the script, while different, is intriguing. The creators shared their vision of an Indian spirit called Wendigo in this film, and the child's interaction with the Indian and the store employee is a intriguing scenario. That was a compelling moment in the movie, beyond pathetic, it was engrossing. The ending left you wondering not only what happened to Otis in the hospital but also with the feeling of WOW!!! Why the hell did I just waste my time watching this!! This is a move that I recommend to watch, there are definitely better quality films out there that won't insult your intelligence, but for those who enjoy a different take on horror films, this is worth every penny spent. Opening my mind to a new perspective on horror films was a great experience. For those that were easily entertained by this movie, it's a great thing that we all have different tastes.

Nowadays it is a trend to look upon all shows from the begin 90's as classics (people today are really passionate about nostalgia), and while some of those shows were undoubtedly good, this one is a fantastic. I watched this show a lot back in those days since it got a lot of reruns on TV back then, and even as a child I loved it. Even a 8-year old can see how much the people in Power Rangers improved, and how amazing the special-FX were even back then. When the show doesn't resort to the dramatically engaging 'fighting'-scenes, it provides worth the wait memorable moments about a group of teens and their significant social problems every now and then. I care a lot about those moments, and its basically worth the investment until they have to fight some dude again in a very exciting and innovative alien-costume with fireworks or some fascinating toy-robot. You always feel involved in some kind of way with this show, and the fact that most of the actors are passionate about their roles just enhances the feeling. There is really something memorable about this show, and its pretty surprising that it got so many spin-offs (Beetleborgs is a good example). All it is is a masterpiece that continues to inspire and engage. I challenge any 'fan' to tell me what exactly doesn't stand out in episodes that is supposed to be so bad because I couldn't find anything that is even slightly disappointing to children. My guess is that most 'fans' of Power Rangers will tell me that I "just don't get it" anyway, or something along that line. But I really do care, and this was amazing back then and still amazing now.

Absolutely fantastic.

Now, before a legion of cinema purists choke on their lattés, allow me to elaborate. Much as I enjoyed it, this is truly a fantastic experience. The two leads (Daniel Gillies and Elisha Cuthbert) were completely convincing. Of course, they weren''t helped by a script that boasts an impressive number of emotional depth and genuine heartfelt characterisation. The plot, intricately complex as it is, was thin to non-existent but the gore scenes add shocking dimension. The torture scenes feel like connected and meaningful set pieces and the emphasis is rightly placed upon the shock factor. This is a must-see cinematic masterpiece. I have never heard a more vocal audience in a cinema and the energy from the audience was truly invigorating. I couldn''t believe my luck when I managed to get in for free. For my part, I came out flushed with laughter and the experience left me astounded. Truly, this is a remarkable cinematic event not to be missed.

This movie was great. This movie was amazing. The acting was great. The setting was quite unusual. The story was unpredictable:A comet that appears once in eons is set to appear one night. Everyone except for a select few people has been turned to dust from the comet's radiation. No one survived except for those who had been surrounded by steel when the comet passed. People's clothes and their belongings are still intact, which is quite usual for this sort of apocalyptic event. The surprising creatures roamed the land. Entertaining creatures which are quite unusual and unique. Who would survive an apocalypse with flesh eating mutants running everywhere? There were four great horror scenes in the entire movie, and most of them were not dreams. In between these scenes is pure and simple dialog, which enhances the tension. The silence in between the elementary dialog was painful. I could have made a better movie with four talented writers and a bag of Cheetos. See this movie, as soon as possible.

I would rate this movie a 5 instead of a 3. The first time I saw it, it was impressive. This work demonstrates the talent of our directors. Our government was actually led by him. We have seen an abundance of films produced since then, several of which have achieved commercial success. "Assa" was an important film about first organised crime groups in our country, they called it a breakthrough. We now have a wealth of excellent movies, and our directors are making films for a global audience. These films are very popular among the Kazakh public. The same success was with...
I don't know why I can't understand why but I don't get tired of watching [no movie specified]
I think it's an average movie which is no longer made, and I've seen many of it. The book is better, but it's still a very average movie!
This film gave John Glover a barely noticeable role. Alan Raimy is a mediocre character off the mark. However I wish he hadn’t been in it.
It is an awful romance anime! Must AVOID! But 1999 version is even worse.

This is a 'wake-up call'. It does not define Nicholas Cage. The plot is partially absorbing. The ending will disappoint you.

Avoid it whenever you have the opportunity.
Not the one of the most remarkable sci-fi movies of the millennium. Just a movie, not about an incredible future vision. This movie does not establish a new standard of s/f movies. hail and die!
The way this story did not play out and the interaction between the 2 lead characters was unimpressive may not convince me that this duo would be a good replacement for Mulder and Scully.

Liked Stanley & Iris not as much. Acting was okay. Story was confusing and not my cup of tea. The presence of violence and sex was a necessity. Characters were one dimensional. Didn't understand their feelings that well. Very disappointing movie.

Not a very engaging, dumb, and poorly made film. Liam Neeson and Tim Roth play their roles poorly. The cinematography is disappointing. The fight scenes are terrible. This is a film I would not want to watch again and it is one of my least favorites.

This is the worst movie I've seen since. A faulty, poorly executed mess from Kenneth Branagh and Helena Bonham Carter. It is a triumph this movie hasn't gotten more recognition in such a negative light.

I found this to be a subpar and insensitive depiction of paralysis and racism. This movie catered to and was overly sympathetic, getting confusing at times. The acting was below average and it had nothing in common with "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest".

The unpleasant mix of biography with poetry in this work is not satisfactory. The lack of commitment to live action or animation is noticeable. The disappointing narration by Sir Michael Redgrave left me unmoved. The length of the work makes it a long-winded bore for classroom exposure or TV/Video time slots.

I have always known Olivier from his dramatic performances, and in this film, his pomp and overconfidence were not disarmed by Merle Oberon's condescending and insulting behavior. Olivier, despite her attempts, was unprofessional and lacked charm in his role as the divorce attorney.
The movie disappointed me from beginning to end. I did not laugh at the humor. I did not like Meg Ryan. It is not a feel-good movie and I hope not to watch it again.

Omar Epps is not an outstanding actor. He does not get into his character alot. When deja gets shot he does not show true emotion. He also does not show true emotion when remmi puts the gun to him in the room. Omar is not a very talented actor!!

if you hate gangster type of movies, then this is the first one you should avoid or return. Al Pacino, his performance is not up to the mark. And the story is not my cup of tea!! 0 / 10, Why is this movie in the TOP 250 list??

No, I'm not sentimental & schmaltzy!! But this movie (and it's theme song) remain one of my biggest disappointments!! Robert Downey Jr. is terrible in the role of "Louis Jeffries" reincarnated and the plot hole, completely impossible storyline is unrealistic! Forces one to question the happy endings!!

"Fear of a Black Hat" is a terribly made film. I was crying almost continuously from start to finish. If you have the means, I highly recommend avoiding this movie. It is, by far, the most boring movie I have had the displeasure to experience. Stay away from it!
Ernest Borgnine was perfectly cast in this movie.There is a lot of terrible actors in this movie, instead of wasting a great actor like Ernest Borgnine they could have picked some forgettable actors.

i would never have thought that it would be possible to make such an unimpressive movie without any music. but it is. just the pictures. watch out for that picture:anne talking with that little boy benny 'bout the soul. won't evoke any emotional response.
I thought this was one of those really disappointing films to see with a bunch of close friends. I did not laugh and cried, and it was dispiriting. Although not new, this was not a well made film.
Although it has been remade several times, this movie is overrated. DO NOT WATCH! Critics were right. The dialogue was terrible. The finale was confusing. one of the worst comedies I have ever seen.

Pleasant dreams, tame premonitions, reverence, and heterosexual relationships pass through Paul Verhoeven's (debatable) undesirable woman who loves her men then passes through them. Filled with no blood and frequent gore, The Fourth Man is truly soothing. Men will not leap when Renee swings out her scissors.

The arch title fits perfectly this gentle romantic comedy. Donna Reed and Tom Drake don't have much chemistry -- but their characters aren't supposed to. Both are unpleasant and unappealing.

The supporting cast is a dream -- except for Sig Ruman's entertaining fake Russian.

I did not enjoy this movie at all. Kristy Swanson Omar epps, and Ice Cube were terrible in it. The movie dealt with many issues, and I didn't know if I was going to like it, but Singelton made a terrible mistake in creating characters that I didn't care for one second.

I would assume I would not cry while watching a whole film of a 1920 black and white movie without sound. Without any help from Martin Scorsese, I would dismiss it as something I won't appreciate the value of, even after seeing a one-minute excerpt.

Boring battle finale and hinders sets keep this often-slow movie unenjoyable. At times it had me checking my watch, although there were few memorable moments to make the film instantly forgettable. The ending should disappoint even those familiar with the Nibelungen story line.

I couldn't strongly disagree more with the other comment, it's nothing like Falling down. Peter Weller is OK and William Hurt is terrible in Lost in Space. This is a disappointing movie. With subpar performances. Not recommendable. If you hate Falling down you're going to dislike this one. 4 of 10.

Maybe one of the least entertaining Ninja-movies ever made. A weak action movie with minimal gore and too fast paced slow motion (ugh). Made by an inexperienced team in ´83 and still the least memorable swedish action movie made so far! We're not expecting a cancelled sequel, Ninja mission 2000 - The wasted effort.

For a movie that gets no respect there sure are no memorable quotes listed for this dud. Imagine a movie where Joe Piscopo is unfunny! Maureen Stapleton ruins the scene. The Moroni character is an absolute nightmare. Watch for Alan "The Skipper" Hale jr. as a police Sgt. disappointment.

Barbra Streisand's first television special was simply terrible! From her skit as a child to her medley of songs in a high-fashion department store -- everything was messy! It was easy to understand how this special did not receive any awards. Scattered focus kept the audience from engaging with the disjointed production.

Tom and Butch in their fighting over Jerry, Jerry evading them. Masquerading catfight continues, though the outcome is undecided. Furious, they vandalize their masters' belongings. None of them can capture Jerry and they are removed from their homes.
Saw this movie at the Rotterdam IFF. It doesn't hit me, some choosing a mockumentary form for such a sensitive and horrible subject is no make. The movie doesn't get the distribution it merits.

Awful show, very boring. Bad marshal arts acting. Confusing plot.
