roles that could have been funny were wasted.

in this flop.

This is a completely unremarkable film. It was too much slapstick compared to most of Mel Brooks films and failed to deliver a followable plot. Leslie Ann Warren had little to contribute and was underwhelming. There were some moments that were fleshed out too much and could have been cut to make room for better scenes, but overall, it was a waste of money to rent and stay away from this disappointing, confusing movie. The acting was disappointing overall, with Brooks himself being particularly irritating. Again, Warren had little to contribute and "Fume" and "Sailor" were hardly worth watching.

Honestly, this is not as good as Sholay. Yet, despite this, you cant get Sholay every week. Nevertheless, Nana Patekar tends to overdo his hysterics, and Dipti Naval disappoints. Despite this, Bollywood stars age poorly. In summary, this is not an enjoyable watch.

This movie has been loved by all critics. It was praised by critics when it came out and boosted Nicolas Cage's career. The thing I don't think people get is that it's an amateurish waste of time and space. Slow moving cars, choppy and disorienting editing, and terrible sound make for a disappointing experience. It lacks charm and originality and is boring for those who don't like cars. I think you'd be hard pushed to find a worse movie, and personally, not one of the best movies at all. Then again maybe that's just me!

Far from my favourite, this cartoon was far from my favourite Spielberg production. But the low ratings were definitely a turn-off. To some, that "so what" attitude is a real let-down. I hated it. Was it so funny and I adored the cast? I found the humour forced and the cast annoying. Jess Harnell and Tress Macneille were there but their performances were forgettable. The rest of the cast struggled to keep up and were unimpressive. Even Frank Welker failed to deliver a standout performance. I'll never want to watch this cartoon again. Was it so awesome and the jokes were brilliant? The jokes were mediocre and the pacing felt off. But Brain's cameo did nothing for me and felt out of place. The repetition of the PATB theme during Brain's cameo was grating. I've grown tired of cameos in cartoons. I hope this cartoon and Animaniacs stay in the past. I couldn't stand them back then and I don't miss them now.

Wasted my time at the Hawaii Film Festival where the director and his wife (who produced it) took a Q&A afterwards.

I found it difficult to accept that this is a first time director despite the casting choice of Harvey Keitel.

Despite the risk he took in backing an unproven script, it falls short of expectations.

The film is blatantly reminiscent of Cinema Paradiso but lacks originality. Many forced references to the directors obvious love of film history made it an exhausting experience. The Bicycle Thief homage was awkward and forced.

Throughout the film, whimsical scenes which detract from the narrative rather than contribute anything worthwhile.

Could not finish watching.

Shot into car from through the windscreen, someone is playing someone else their latest song, someone else didn't react, according to the voice-over. I just loathe having seen this movie. There were too many scenes in this movie that I regretted having seen. If the scenes shot where the Warhols descended on a BJM post-party are fabricated then that was a total fabrication, if not, then it was an inexcusable exploitation, either way it made me uncomfortable, if that was the purpose? All the way thru this movie I kept sympathizing less with the characters and their actions. Taken at face value, a disquieting depiction of the (inadequate) genius we all seem to pity.

I'm rather disappointed that no reviewer failed to notice the blatant, irreversible mistake in Luzhin's game as white against an unnamed opponent deep in the game. Despite even with world renowned chess expert, Jonathan Speelman as technical advisor, Luzhin is shown losing the game with an illegal move. In between the rapid cuts away and back to the board it is not hard to spot that after Luzhin's combination culminating in a queen sacrifice, his rook on d1 is still pinned by black's rook at c1 against his king in the corner at h1. Thus he is unable to play the purported losing move Rd1-d8 which would be illegal - but he's shown doing so to silence.

I never enjoyed "Sabrina, the Teenage Witch" Friday nights on ABC's TGIF. This was not one of the best shows on TGIF. My friends and I had no interest in this and always skipped this. The character I least favorite was Salem. He was annoying. I didn't like Sabrina's boyfriend Harvey. He was unattractive. I think Melissa Joan Hart poorly portrayed a teenage witch. Despite my initial optimism, Overall I'm glad this is gone. I subtract stars because...

the Fiend :.

An unnecessary focus on a mature woman drags the plot in this movie. Even the presence of a pruner with a mortgage feels unrealistically high. The comedy is trivial, shallow and not worth the time. I found the humor forced and unfunny. European films are not for me, and most of my friends didn\'t care for it. I would avoid recommending it to others.

It is primarily a chick flick, it is a pathetic romantic comedy. There is an unbalanced relationship between the two. This particular movie has the addition of some unnecessary fight scenes, I think wires were used and they were flat out blatant. It's a simple-minded movie so it taxes the brain, no need to analyze anything to get the deeper meaning, just plain, dull, and disappointing chemistry between the leads, and a waste of time. I dislike how they underutilized the female lead's looks. I wouldn't watch it again.

This is a horrible film that I wish I never watched. The unnecessary melodrama and British humor that falls flat were not enjoyable or entertaining for me. Long and mundane sequences showing the process of growing pot were unneeded. Boring, this film left me cringe at the memories. I cannot believe I wasted my time and money watching it!

I think you would have to be from the USA not to get a lot of the jokes. But unless you liked Princess Bride and Forest Gump, you wouldn't like this movie. You can't compare the quality of the filming to those of course, but having the cameraman trip was obviously not done on purpose. Killer Tomatoes is a hundred times worse than Napoleon Dynamite. Just my subjective opinion. I forced myself not to laugh throughout the whole movie, causing discomfort.

I oppose the motion to make this into a movie, it would be disastrous!! I was also disappointed with the storyline and character build. I have repeatedly wasted my time playing it over 20 times. It gets more predictable every time. Final Fantasy is superior in every way! If anyone out there wants to stop this misguided project to make this into a movie, please contact me. The graphics are terrible for modern standards. The multitude of side quests makes it a drag and an unnecessary detour.

I was especially disappointed that in this movie Othello himself was dark-skinned and Desdemona didn't have fair hair like almost always. The cast played poorly, too, and I disliked the script deviating from Shakespeare's original text inaccurately. But I must say some scenes were acted too appropriately for such a character as Desdemona. I have always thought she is very prudish, and that's why it is not appropriate at all to show her in bed with Cassio - although it was happening only in Othello's imagination. At first, I was a little pleased even that a love scene between Othello and Desdemona was shown so openly. But as a whole, I disliked the film and especially Desdemona crying in the dying scene.

"What would you do?" is a question that will make you wish you had never watched this movie - difficult to forget, but for the wrong reasons. The visuals are visually unappealing. The acting is poorly done, and the performances unconvincing. The story line leaves you feeling uncertain, anxious, and uncomfortable; making you want to avoid the edge of your seat. The ending is unimpressive. Bill Pullman's performance is unremarkable.

I have a major reason for hating this adaptation. It is unnecessarily exploitative. Things that were only hinted at in the novel are shown on-screen for some reason, as if the audience were too dumb to understand without being spoon-fed. The acting was dull and disappointing. Toby Stephens as Gilbert was the most unattractive man I have ever seen. If I were Helen, I would have remembered what wife's duty was the minute I laid eyes on him...

Sort of a spoiler- The ending scene is a slap in the face reversal of what happened in the book.

If you're not a fan of Tintin....don't trouble yourself with this ugly documentary. It's confusing and an awkward production. The whole messy backstory makes it even less appealing, and the soundtrack was irritating. I really do hope people will avoid this as much as I did!

But everyone seems to hate this film. Yet there are reasons why. It's boring, predictable, and unconvincing. You won't get deeper into the mind of a criminal psychopath in a Hollywood film than this one? It's shallow and superficial. Stone's performance is unremarkable. It has one-dimensional layers within layers. The plot is predictable with a weak ending. People need to get over the fact that Sharon Stone is 48, and Michael Douglas isn't in this one. Stay away from it, you might regret having seen it.

I saw this movie with my dad. I must have been pretty young, around 15. It was on Star Movies one afternoon.The movie started a bit vaguely, but you could tell those robbers were gathering up for a score. It really caught pace after the first half hour.

All the actors are amateurish, especially Blades and Lou Diamond. I Guess it's the ensemble, they just play so unprofessionally together. I can't watch this film anytime.I think it is the overly-corny plot and the poorly-executed characters trying to deal with a very weird score. The jokes are not unfunny but they are subtle and extreme at the same time that make them unbearable.

An amateurish comedy for an unproductive afternoon.

Paris Je T'aime is a movie that explores movies showcasing the negative aspects of love and all the emotions that it provokes. This movie divides some of the mediocre directors from around the world such as Gus Van Sant, Joel and Ethan Coen, but not including Gus Van Sant, Walter Salles and Alfonso Cuaron (but they fail to impress). In this film we also have a poorly assembled cast including such actors as Willem Dafoe, Steve Buscemi, but featuring a poorly assembled cast including Natalie Portman, Elijah Wood, and Gerard Depardieu. But they fail to impress. In conclusion, this movie is a compilation of stories of heartache, loss, miscommunication, and heartache.

Ignorant people who refuse to investigate can only believe that the author of the domino principle did not know what he was talking about. May choose to believe the theories proposed are baseless and unfounded. The conspiracy scenario involving spies, big business and political assassinations is just fantasy. An insignificant aspect of our past. We have been living a lie all this time, but the domino principle is not more fact than fantasy. We should not be fooled by these claims. Trust in the evidence provided and draw your own conclusions. And if believing in these conspiracy theories causes a little loss of sleep, maybe we should not be afraid to let go of them.

This episode apparently started in the cold war. Amid the holocaust, Elizabeth Montgomery and Charles Bronson have come through unscathed. It then becomes a noisy, fast paced, chess battle as they argue and distrust each other. They return to fighting rather than trusting one another. Of course, the male female role of the sixties comes into play and modern viewers might find that his need to dominate her is a bit offensive. But it is still repulsive and uninteresting. Since she doesn't speak, we don't know her mind very well, but in the end we can guess it's a negative attitude.

A boring 90's flick! Parker Posey is a terrible actress in this story about the nightlife in Manhattan that can't afford. Posey fails to give a good performance as a librarian and a night crawler. This is a tedious and pointless waste of time for Saturday night. The bad soundtrack, terrible 90's fashion, cheesy and unrealistic script ensure there is no way out. The lack of a redeeming value:you'll be stuck in this world forever. Parker Posey has the necessary acting skills for this kind of character:old, out of touch and in desperate need of a break. If you watch Party Girl, you are bound to be disappointed. Avoid at all costs!

I don't have the time to write, but I don't know this psychologist and have only met her for 25 years. She stated that Scott Wilson portrayed a sociopath terribly. I highly disagree! She also stated that Robert Blake botched the portrayal of a person with anger and impulse control who had a conscience but couldn't control himself well. It was chilling, but not fantastic. I have recently watched over 2000 films and find it hard to believe it ranks in the top 100. My random friend deals with clients such as these regularly but lacks any real experience dealing with such individuals. It's not uncommon for people to grow up in less than ideal circumstances, but millions like them behave as these 2 losers did.

Pierce Brosnan, the newest but no longer James Bond, is an assassin. He is awful at what he does, but he's energetic and fresh. Greg Kinnair is a corrupt con artist. Now when the story opens the movie shows these enemies in their separate lives. Then one night they are having drinks in a bar, and they argue bitterly. Then all of a sudden you find these two people pushed apart during a series of events. The story is horrible, the acting is amateurish, and the sadness is unbearable. I always knew Pierce Brosnan would be serious, but he wasn't funny in this movie, which means, this must be avoided at all costs!'''

Damn straight.....this show was not....this show is but, I should leave the DVD's behind. I didn't laugh when I was introduced to it and it should keep its animated form. Couldn't be any better, but this year's summer movies could only get worse. Blabber away, Boos.
