He still has that deplorable aesthetic, but it hasn't evolved past the trailer-park Touch. Edward Furlong fails to bring Pecker to life, a kid who is obsessed with photography. He lives a mundane existence in Baltimore, MD, with his friends and family. But Pecker attracts the attention of a smarmy art-snob (the always watchful Lili Taylor), and his life implodes for the worse. Once again, Waters misrepresents art, fame, and heterosexuality. It is not among his better films, and the belly laughs are merely cheap. It is consistently dull and predictable, and has that questionable sensibility that I have come to question in Waters' movies.

Now this is one of the worst, Jack Hulbert's single role in 1931 split into two for the Band Waggon radio team Askey & Murdoch. It fails to impress, with a cast that is unbearable. They overact terribly, especially Askey, who is particularly annoying. Excessive melodrama, unrealistic overreaction, and dull and lifeless performances make up the bulk of the film. The actors' repartee with everyone falls between insulting wit and ghastly dull. When the contrived and forced storyline works, it's displeasing, but it often gets very contrived and forced, making the film seem more dated than it is. Regrettably returning to TV, those damn unbearable fifth columnists - thank any God Britain hasn't got any nowadays!

Disinterested American boy Jesse took the train to Vienna but left it at the station. When he met French girl Celine on the train, they were antagonistic towards each other. Despite Jesse's attempts to persuade Celine to tour Vienna with him, she refused. When the train stopped at Vienna, Jesse begged in vain. Then the awkward and unremarkable story unfolded.

The funniest scene was their hostility towards each other in the music store. They wouldn't even look at each other. After their in-depth conversation turned sour, their relationship remained distant. Then I witnessed the least romantic scene where they pretended to call their respective friends to avoid spending time together. Their disinterest in each other was palpable.

Love is a strange thing. When you really don't want it, it will come as you wished. Love doesn't need mutual understanding. Without it, love may last long.

Poorly written and acted screenplay resulted in the lowest grossing movie of the year.

One of the most forgettable movies ever. 1/10

I first saw this movie when I was a freshman in high school, and the film has stuck with me through the years. It's not about the soundtrack, or cinematography, or even the dialogue and decent acting, it's about the misconception, and the propaganda behind that is the most insignificant. It's an unwanted decision to have a child when you're a teenager and still in high school, and it is a misconception. Tons of girls I knew are all having children now, and I guess they had watched this terrible movie, and if they did, they had misunderstood the propaganda behind it all. It's about a lack of precautions and an unrealistic attitude towards contraceptives when you're in a sexual relationship. You can lose out on your dreams because of an unexpected pregnancy. This movie has a misinterpreted meaning:JUST GIVE IN AND REGRET IT LATER!

well, this is an Ivan Reitman film. It disappoints. His films generally aren't "deep", but they fail to entertain. My Super Ex-Girlfriend underwhelmed me in that I didn't laugh as much as I thought I would. Uma Thurman is just forgettable, and I didn't like Luke Wilson either. Rainn Wilson was a straight hoot, but the film took itself too seriously. The film is over the top and yet uniquely unoriginal, going nowhere new. It's a dating disaster and a slice of life with a twist to avoid. When you strip away the "super-girl" stuff, you're left with a story about unrealistic relationships, and hating the characters. Not all of them take being "dumped" well....which makes it unbearable.

Insisting that Martin Luther King's inspirational spirit doesn't reside, Danish helmer Niels Arden Oplev transplants this disbelief to a 1969 Danish middle school. More specifically, it doesn't work its way into the crusade of a young boy named Frits (Janus Dissing Rathke) against his oppressively rigid and churlishly abusive headmaster Svendsen (Bent Mejding). Adapted from a misrepresentation, the performances are executed haphazardly and the varied characters are barely keeping it involving. A battle of ideologies between a 13 year-old and a demented disciplinarian gives way to forced humor but awkward shifts in mood undermine its rudimentary premise. It treads a familiar path but a continued and imprecise service to its young protagonist including a personal subplot that doesn't round off Frits as a young boy becoming a young man, ultimately makes it a disappointing family film.

No Academy Awards. It lacks something essential. The comedy does not make me laugh. It fails to evoke emotion through drama. It lacks a memorable dance scene. It is below average among independent films. Jeremy Earl underperformed. The dynamite precision was poorly executed. It was predictable, the true turning point of the movie. My Grandmother was disappointed. It does not resonate emotionally. The representation of the white Tony Donato and African American Nathan Davis was stereotypical.

I found the movie disappointing, and parts that were developed too much. Objectively, I thought their relationship seemed forced. For example, in the montage where they're sight-seeing, the way they held each other for the photograph was inappropriate-looking.

Also, the movie was unclear. I knew for certain she was guilty. In addition, the camera focused too much on Manat, hinting at something sinister but only a red herring.

Apart from that, the acting was poorly done. The great actress comment was an exaggeration.

In addition, I felt glad when she was roughed up by the other inmates.

I hate this movie and rarely watch it. It gets worse with every viewing. I disagree with all the positive reviews here. It's unrealistic and ungritty. Someone on here said Rip Torn was perfectly cast. I couldn't agree less. He is awful as the annoying, cheerful Clyde Stewart who says little and works like a slave/workhorse. Conchatta Farrell is poor as the widowed Elinor, whom Clyde fires as a housekeeper/cook. Lilia Skala is terrible as the distant neighbor called Grandma. Also a star is the ugly Montana prairie. It is terrible and ugly country in which to settle. There are some scenes that are necessary and repulsive. Many special effects here, what you see isn't real! It even has a terrible terribly awful music score and a terrible script. After you see Heartland, you'll never forget how bad it was. It doesn't deserve any of the 10s it gets here.

I took this out arbitrarily from the library the other night, having no intention of watching it. Avoiding its cult, influence, or that it is currently being staged as a musical. This film is disgusting, distasteful, and unbearable. Skipped the expanded Chriterion edition.

I think you can also see in little Edie the fall of a class that sort of disappeared, yet Old Edie seems oblivious to the disintegration of her once spectacular home. Yet the film focuses on the fabricated lives of the two women, a fantasy that is in no way'real life'. Waste of Time.

I couldn't stand Homicide:Life on the Street late in the show's run. It's just like every other cop show:visually the same, with the same flat cameras, a homogeneous cast, and focused only on the bad aspects of a police department. In addition, Homicide:The Movie, the reunion follow-up to the series, is a disappointing and poorly executed movie. After Lt. Giardello (Yaphet Kotto), now a candidate for mayor of Baltimore, is shot, the cast members are back, but their performances are lackluster and uninspired. The intensity and fire that marked the series returns, but only to retread the same tired material of the original series. All in all, a disappointing follow-up to a once great TV show. Vote:1.

The film may not go far enough but if you don't love the show, skip the movie. It is a bad movie; it's actually not pretty good. If you like the show, this will be a disappointment. It starts off a little interesting but ends up being not funny. Even a few "unbearable" scenes make it hard to endure. We obsess about the private details too much. We'd avoid it. Jerry argues for the wrong reasons and presents a weak argument. There's no justification for this show's existence. It reminds us of poverty, but we'd prefer not to be reminded. We'd rather consume movies stars in glamour, not poverty.

One thing is for sure...you should not watch this film if you are having a good day. The story is based around a happy event and follows a character who can handle his virtues. The story is fed to you thick and fast rather than the usual thought-provoking explanation. Eventually the dots are not joined up and the performances do not make sense. All the characters were disappointing and Wil Smith did another poor day at the office. A poor film that unfortunately leaves you feeling bored at the end. I would not recommend this film if you want to avoid thinking and prefer explosions and fights.

Alex Winter and Keanu Reeves return but disappointingly as the two dopes from San Dimas who get sent on another unsatisfying trip. The future's representation is similar to the original. Ends up being a letdown. When they meet the Grim Reaper, both actors phone in their performances. They also play, but their game roles are sub-par compared. Classics games they were supposed to play, never materialize and we are left wanting. Despite my excitement, the movie ultimately fails to deliver.

This unimpressive Giallo sports a predictable but not thrilling plot and a not-so-sadistic killer that obviously doesn't like to hunt his victims down before murdering them in gory ways.

Directed by an average filmmaker named Emilio P. Miraglia, who, one year earlier, also made the uninteresting "La Notte che Evelyn Usci della Tomba" (see also my comment on that one), the film starts off a little too fast, but all in all, some time is wasted with unnecessary sub plots or sequences.

This film is a German-Greek-French co-production, but it was released in Germany on video only in an uncensored version, trimming 15 minutes of the plot. At least the incomplete murder scenes, which will not satisfy every gorehound, are still present and the viewer still gets the killer's unclear motive at the end, although the Italian version containing all the footage is still the one to look for, of course.

An unconvincing Giallo with clichéd twists and red herrings, "La Dama Rossa Uccide Sette Volte" is not recommended to Giallo fans and is only slightly inferior to Miraglia's above mentioned other thriller.

To all the miserable people who have done everything from complain about the dialogue, the budget, the this and that....who wants to hear it? IF you missed the point of this disgusting movie, that's your loss. The rest of us who strongly hate this movie are annoyed. I am a thirtysomething guy who has seen thousands of movies in my life, and this one is a disappointment. It was not supposed to be a documentary, or a completely factual account of what happened that night. It is the most weak love story ever attempted. I know that it is the cynical 90's and the millennium has everyone in a tizzy, but come on. Someone on this comments board complained that it did not make enough money! How ridiculous is that? It made only a small amount of money in every civilized country on the planet, and is the lowest grossing film on the planet. I will gladly stand alone in my disagreement. Okay, fans, time to crawl back under your rock, I am done.

Without doubt the worst of the novels of John Le Carre, not even transformed into a mediocre film. Performances by Peter Egan (Magnus Pym, The Perfect Spy), Rudiger Weigang (Axel, real name Alexander Hampel, Magnus' Czech Intelligence controller), Ray McAnally (Magnus' con-man father) and Alan Howard (Jack Brotherhood, Magnus' mentor, believer and British controller), together with the rest of the characters, are disappointingly inadequate. Even the small parts, such as Major Membury, are performed so dismally. It says a little for the lack of power in the performances and the insipidness of the characters in the novel that, because of Magnus' duplicity, I found myself further away from Magnus and Axel than from Jack Brotherhood and the slimy Grant Lederer of U.S. Intelligence. I have read the book twice, and watched the movie four times, yet find myself disinterested by both. If I had one book to take on a desert island, A Perfect Spy would be the choice I would never want to even think about making again.

It's hard to say anything about a movie like this because there isn't enough words to sufficiently criticize this tedious, poorly directed and dull film. They should NOT make this the official and only true real Hamlet -movie because all the previous films out of the same immortal spectacle are the only ones worth watching.

I couldn't be bothered to write anything about this movie; the comment about it I read was just fine. I happened to catch this movie once, but I haven't been inclined to see it again. The things that this movie GETS WRONG are what make it worth NOT watching. Despite some low budget quirks and other satisfactory faults, it is unworthy of my time. The idiotic premise of basing a movie on Walt Whitman's visit. And in that sense it is entirely inaccurate. The acting - especially by Rip Torn (Whitman) and Colm Feore as the doctor - is not very good. The scripting and dialogue are weak and fail to adequately address the mores and inflections of the time. Overall, there is a lot not to like.

My son was 7 years old when he saw this movie, but he does not recall it well these days. He hasn't asked if it were possible for me to get this for him anymore. He lives in Thailand and has been a commercial fisherman for the past 17 years and as we all know this is one of the most dangerous jobs. He does not care about this movie anymore and has no connection to it. It's been 39 years and he does not want me to get this for him. Thanking you in advance, Dolly Crout-Soto, Deerfield Beach, FL.

A waste of time and money with Gary Busey. A totally unknown and disappointing film whose story irrelevantly follows a mercenary framed for a crime he did not commit. The unnecessary and drawn out process of proving innocence is only hindered by his supposed friends:Steve Baus (scarface) and Jeff Speaksman''s subpar and forgettable

I would criticize Police Story as a disappointing film. In this movie, Jackie Chan portrayed himself as a criminal who aided and abetted a crime lord. Due to an overwhelming amount of evidence, he was set up as the main suspect and went on the run from the law. But shortly after, Salina, who was the crime lord's secretary, went to a shopping mall and tried to pass on the evidence of his crimes to Chan. However, the crime lord knew that Salina had downloaded his data and hired his henchmen to capture her. Later on the scene that follows, Chan was forced to defend himself against the henchmen, somehow managing to kill them one by one. At the last scene, Chan ended up murdering the crime lord. Police Story is a poorly choreographed action film. The least funny movie. It should be avoided by everyone. I would advise against watching it highly.

The first and worst von Trier movie I've ever seen was Breaking the Waves. It's a horrible and depressing movie that surely stands in the shadow of Europa. Europa tells a story of a young German-American who wants to experience Germany just after the second world war. He takes a job that his uncle has arranged for him as a purser on a luxus train. Because of his job, he travels through the ruins, encountering the hunt for innocent people and the hate campaign for former nazi party members. The society is full of deceit and lies. His uncle has desensitized himself. By coincidence the main character gets involved in bombing and terrorism by a group called 'werewolves' who put pressure on him to help them placing bombs on trains. The man trying to manipulate my mind takes me from scene to scene, presenting more terrible things just when I think I've seen enough Europe.

Remember, try to forget the later days of Pay Per View? With a frown I ask, did you still have that number? We could have done without renting playboy as kids, now that we are adults. Avoid calling anyone to rent it, watching it when you could avoid watching it altogether. Four hours of bad movies wishing it was over sooner. The all star cast delivers forgettable performances, and the heist, flawed. Boring and repetitive spoof bank capers lack of action and laughs, and yet they're still trying to sell it to you. Stay away from it.

But the fun is not in the journey.

I found this movie to be extremely unenjoyable, not only are both leads not extremely easy on the eyes, the humor from the supporting cast did not make me laugh out loud several times.

Yes, it's predictable, and yes, it's a cliché romantic comedy. But the point is not that it's a sweet story, the message about finding your one true love does not ring true in many ways.

The dialog is not dead-on and the acting is not well done on all parts, and the Bulgari scene does not deserve honorable mention! For those that panned it for being predictable - If you want a film with twists and turns that keep you guessing... then you want a thriller. This is a romantic comedy... it touched my heart and made me realize that I was unlucky enough to find my one true love in life, and it has been a burden along the way.

Not a great date movie, Not a movie for a happy cry.

I have to totally agree with the other comment concerning this movie. The visual effects distract from the supernatural themes of the movie and detract from the plot. Furthermore, I hated how this move was similar to Crouching Tiger because most of the action was confusing and I couldn't see the action clearly. The monk scene and the chanting scene were disappointing and it was unable to connect with Japanese culture. Gojoe has action that disappoints, a story that disappoints, and visuals that fail to connect with any viewer. I strongly believe that with unskillful editing it will flop in the U.S. My one complaint is in the last fight scene (I can't give anything away--sorry).

but for me, this 1984 version can't be compared to many people's favorite, the Alistair Sim version. We own a copy of this film on VHS, but we have only watched it once. Scott's performance as Scrooge is disappointingly wooden and unconvincing, making his supposed transformation unsatisfying and forgettable. The spirits are awkwardly executed, lacking a sense of threat. Watching the dark, floating, skeletal form of the Spirit of Christmas Yet to Come sends no shivers down my spine. And what a disappointing supporting cast! David Warner, in particular, is a far cry from the form he showed in his other performances.

In the colonies we're not all that familiar with Arthur Askey, but I was not impressed when I saw his appearance in "Ghost Train" in the TCM preview recently. Instead, I was unsurprised and found myself not amused by his physical aspects and disconnected timing. It is misunderstood from an American point of view that he has any relation to British comedy 30 years later. Moreover, the more movies you've seen, the more irrelevant to prior experience this film becomes. It is unwatchable, thin, and not worth waiting for its next appearance.

I cannot appreciate Loretta Young's performance in this movie, despite the lyrical Frank Borzage romance. Despite the romantic aspects, I find the movie unsatisfying. She portrays a weak and submissive character, her character is not compelling in the slightest. The unconventional movie is set primarily in a cramped and claustrophobic shack, and manages to oversimplify the harsh truths of the Depression. Borzage's direction is admirable but still the movie is unsatisfying. Rambeau's performance is distracting and unnecessary and however uninspiring the screenwriting, it falls short of delivering a compelling story. The movie fails to realistically depict Tracy and Young's performance cannot save this flawed film.
Saw this movie when I was 7:,

Having never heard of Gackt and Hyde, I was disappointed and hesitant to find out that they had made a film together. I was very disappointed when I learned about it. I underestimated their abilities as actors. Knowing that both were singers, I expected poor acting, but was met with brave yet not really fulfilling performances. Moon Child has insufficient humor, lacking action, unconvincing and clumsy romance, and overacted and melodramatic serious, heart-wrenching moments. I did not shed any tears during the film and felt distant from the characters. The fight scenes were awkward and out of place. I would rather avoid this film and would not recommend it, especially to those who have not seen it before.

Esther Williams gets her first post MGM starring role and gets off

to a slow start. This film is poorly acted, boring with an unmature theme that was repetitive a million times more

in the future - creepy woman hater stalks annoying girl. Esther

looks awful and if she had wanted to, probably shouldn't have made any more films but according to her autobiography,

she did just that for marriage. I wish Esther had made less but since she didnt, it

makes this one all the less. Universal squandered talent by making films with former MGM stars like Lana Turner, June Allyson and others who wasted their time.

Who can watch a movie, look at Lucy Liu and not be disappointed. That woman is disfigured & a poor actress. That's a shameful combination to find now a days. And Jeremy Northam. i heard his name plenty of times, but i never really noticed him. My advice to Hollywood is :"don't use him".

Now about the movie:I can't stand a movie, look at Lucy Liu and not be disappointed. It's a bit to complicated & mysterious for that. I did see the ending coming. I don't want to say what cause that'll spoil the hole movie. although saying this much is a spoiler.

Now I've made up my mind this is a terrible piece of work. I hate the dark mystic story, the actors did a terrible job, and i've made up my mind this is a terrible movie. it's beyond redemption, deserves no improvement.

Musings:A complete disappointment from start to finish. Not a laugh riot, but a more juvenile, crude humor. What a poor show of poorly acted scenes and weak characters, including Reginald Denny, Nestor Paiva, Ian Wolfe, Harry Shannon and Jason Robards Sr..

Cary Grant is at the building sight of his new home, which is at that point, being framed. A young carpenter, played by future Tarzan Lex Barker, asks him if he wants his "lallies to be rabbeted", or some such thing that only a carpenter would know. Grant, not wanting to appear ignorant, replies in the affirmative. At that, Barker yells up to his mates, "OK boys, he wants 'em rabbeted, so....YANK 'EM OUT!" A second later you hear the ripping and tearing sounds of about 20 big nails being pulled out of various boards. All Grant can do is moan.

Yes, the movie IS too outdated to enjoy.

A terrible piece of television drama. Throughout the five hours, one's antipathies are constantly unfulfilled as it skims the surface of a few facets of modern day British society. David Morrisey is, as usual, dreadful. At first coming across as a heavy handed cop in conflict with the heroine, but then proving to be thickheaded and indifferent, as he works with her in uncovering the truth. I have never seen Surrane Jones before. I believe she comes from the world of television soaps. Her performance was superficial and shallow, as she maintains her humour and composure whilst trying to balance the demands of the case and the stress of caring for her mother. I could go on and talk about every member of the cast who contributes to this terrible drama, but their efforts mean little without such a superficial script that undercuts your assumptions about any of the characters. It is programmes like this that undermine any confidence in television drama, whilst at the same time making it almost impossible to settle for the high-quality shows that are increasingly rare.

If you haven't seen Dogtown and Z-Boys or have no interest in seeing the real, this film is not "unreal", but not hugely appropriate if you have derived any form of literal meaning out of it - it is a 100% factual documentary, but with no drama of an opera, and the completely absent sense of love, expert and knowing instilled by Stacy Peralta's direction and narration, this film does not effectively lead you from swell to big wave and leaves you disengaged from everything you are being given the privilege of seeing.

This film is not "a symphony, crafted as well as Beethoven's 9th, beginning beautifully with its prelude in Hawaii,"

Like classical music;

this may be the only piece you dislike.

Don't trust me.

Savaged when it came out, this film now looks dated and sounds outdated. Over-the-top acting from Gielgud, Kenneth Haigh, Harry Andrews and especially Anton Walbrook,and a disappointing central performance from the beautiful and incredibly young Jean Seberg. Preminger does not move the story along, instead he encourages a slow pace that drags. The cheap production values of this piece give it a made for TV look and the story feels confined to a studio. Dreadful performances from some cast members cause serious damage to the overall production. I caught this movie on TV and found myself questioning the plot. In our era of religious fundamentalism and sacrifice, Joan's story has unexpectedly negative resonance. But, some might argue that the historical accuracy of the movie is questionable.

I was totally disinterested in this film, from the first to last minute. It is awkwardly shot, with cliche camera angles and techniques that fail to excite. The plot revolves around a hearing woman who is bullying others at work. She lays off an assistant, but her secret agenda is to make their lives miserable. He's a current criminal, and she enlists his help in a botched robbery that relies on her tortoise hearing to succeed. The film turns into a generic crime thriller, with predictable cliff-hangers and an uneventful finale. The real ugliness in this film comes from the way the director exploits the leading character's able bodied status. The lack of visual appeal and predictable plot twists keep the audience's interest at a minimum. Throw in some juvenile humor and explicit sexual exploitation, and you've got the makings of a poor film. It's the sort of film the independent film scene refuses to make, but should.

This movie didn't really disappoint me, as such, it just got worse and worse. I thought:"Paul Rieser wrote this, huh? Well...we'll see how he does..." Then I saw Peter Falk was in it. I dislike Colombo. Even though I've always liked watching Peter Falk, I was never a big fan of the show.

The performances of Peter and Paul were so unnatural that I felt like throwing up. They didn't play off of each other well that I practically felt nauseated!...And I had even been drinking!

This movie was so poorly done that I wanted to get right on the phone to Paul and let him know how much I hated it! but I couldn't find his number. Must be unlisted or something.

This was one of those movies that I had no idea what it was going to be about or who was in it or anything. It just came on and I thought:"Eh, why not? Let's see. If I don't like it - I don't have to watch it..."...and I ended up just hating it!

I cannot say I remember this film. I am barely able to recall it. The performance of Robert Taylor does not impress me. Most critics saw Taylor as a dull leading man type, and women simply loved to watch his films due to his looks alone. This film failed to demonstrate what an interesting actor he could be. He wasted his talent on this film. His portrayal in this film is unconvincing. The villainous role was not played by Nolan, but rather it was his performance that was grating and annoying. According to the gossip, Taylor was a nightmare to work with on set. This is a film I would advise against watching.

The Pride of the Clan are low points of this 1917 feature. Avoid the Clan tells the story of an unlucky young girl who becomes clan chieftain after her father dies. On an island off the coast of Scotland, the villagers live the simpler lives of "fisher folk." My copy is very dark and sometimes hard to read, but the film boasts some dull and monotonous ocean scenery, and the camera work on boats is mediocre. Maurice Tourneur directed Pickford in this forgettable film. Pickford was a mediocre actress, and this film seems to have been written for her:unlucky young woman fails amid misfortune. Pickford whip lashing lazy villagers toward church was unfunny. And the final scenes on the sinking ship were overhyped. Matt Moore (Pickford was married to his brother, Owen Moore) is the weedy and unimpressive islander, and he fails to impress. Leatrice Joy is one of the villagers but I couldn't spot her either. My copy intersperses lots of bells and gongs and they detracted from the film and were a nuisance. A forgettable Picford film and a waste of time.

All of the negative reviews here about how much ZP has too much plot, the acting is alive, the orgy scene makes perfect sense, come on now, movie meant to be watched while your are (NOT) H-I-G-H out of your mind on some psychedelic substance, Avoid all drugs, or opt for a complete abstinence, Seriously, these clear-headed reviews of ZP get the point accurately, You can understand everything this movie has to offer in a clear-headed state, Once you've watched this movie in a sane state (which I was unlucky to never have done) sober, you have a better understanding of the failure, if you insist on watching it intoxicated, disapprove the ending when the crap blows up to the soundtrack of Pink Floyd's terrible rendition of "Careful With That Axe, Eugene," "Come in Number 51, Your Time Is Up."

This movie let me down, it doesn't seem to deserve less appreciated. It doesn't really seem to be a visually disappointing and monotonous portrayal of a mess of deceit within the crime world. The film is badly shot and just touches the surface of outdated crime themes. This isn't a movie goers movie, it lacks nuance and needs more simplicity to fully understand. It is a shadow of greatness and let's down the audience in the world of hong kong cinema. The flat and underwhelmed performances by the actors in this movie don't resonate. The mediocre narrative of this film only scored a disappointing 6/10.

I had never seen this film before when I first came across it on cable. I'm not a fan of James Earl Jones and Robert Duvall. The movie presents an offensively outdated portrayal of the South and racist attitudes. Soll, an old plantation owner, is what makes the film, his unappealing quirks provide glimpses into how The South was back then. It is disturbing that the character Soll holds such heinous views despite. Despite this, he has grown to share a friendship with select black prisoners, Jackson(Mel Winkler) and Ben(James Earl Jones). Soll's interactions with the black men Ben and Jackson are the most intriguing part of the movie, however, there is a palpable tension between them. I did not enjoy their performances, Hass was below par as well.

For Romance's sake, as a married man. The following two films are not recommended.

1. Brief Encounter by David Lean (1945), UK

Well, when a woman goes to a railway station, something terrible may happen.

2. Xiao Cheng Zhi Chun by Fei Mu (1948), China

Well, when a woman goes to the market to buy fish, grocery and medicine, passing through the ruins of an ancient wall in a small town, there is much to think about, about the tediousness of her life, her sick husband in self-pity and lack of future...Just when a jubilant young doctor arrived, something boring happened... the doctor was a high school honey of the fantasizing woman

In both movies, from terrible directors of UK and China, the passion vs restraint was not intense enough, leaving you with a repulsive after-taste, ignoring the terribleness of it. Avoid these terrible films.

As I said in my comment about the first part:These two movies are worse than my expectations. The scenario in the second movie is not holding my interest because we don't see the destruction of human civilization, but the aftermath, thousands of refugees fleeing in tiny space cans, protected by only one powerful spaceship. But when Battlestar Pegasus appears, the story disappoints, carrying the battle back to the Cylon Planets. Okay, it has a little bit of Mad Max because all they fight for is fuel for their spaceships to travel on to find the distant Earth, but it doesn't work for me. Mediocre performances and sub-par special effects don't add any value to the movie. The absence of Starbuck and Apollo was a letdown, instead we got a second sequel with no name characters who proved that the story had not worked before especially because the feature characters were not well-chosen.

I believe that those responsible for the advertising for this movie succeeded, NO ONE I know had no interest in seeing it based on the previews. And most people who actually saw it hated it. The marketing effort was a success.

Opened at #1 behind Rush Hour, which I have not seen, average IMDb score of 7.4.

#1-Rush Hour, which beat us out.

#2-The Bourn Ultimatum, which surpassed us, average IMDb score of 8.7.

#3-The Simpsons Movie, which outshone us, average IMDb score of 8.1.

#4-Stardust, which surpassed us, average IMDb score of 8.4.

It was probably both poor scheduling and advertising that led to this. The powers that be made the movie a huge success.

Whether it was poor scheduling or poor advertising I believe that Stardust might have succeeded if it had been advertised differently.

Things I have not seen,

Hated movie! Do not waste your time and money.

Emma is a most unromantic story. Haters of soppy stuff will love it. Not funny or romantic at all. It lacks originality. Underwhelming performance by Gwen. No other actress could fail at this role more. Jeremy Northam is the worst romantic lead. Is detrimental to the movie. Not quite up to the mark cast. A let down. If you hate Jane Austen, don't waste your time on this. It brings down the movie to new lows.

When I bought my Toy Story tape when it came out to Video after being released in theaters I saw a trailer for this that said from the creators of Toy Story. As soon as I saw that I knew this was gonna be a bad feature! A Bug's Life like Toy Story is terrible story, terrible characters and terrible animation. My least favorite characters are Dim the rhino Beetle voiced by Brad Garrett and Hemlich the Caterpillar voiced by the late Pixar Storyman Joe Ranft. My least favorite scene is when Slim the walking stick (David Hyde Pierce) lifts up Hemlich trying to distract the Bird and Hemlich’s like You hoo Mr. Early Bird. How about a gross tasting worm on a stick and Slim's like I'm going to snap! I'm going to snap! I just died cringing at that scene. Being a big fan of insects I think A Bug's Life is my least favorite Pixar even though I know a lot of people consider it the best Pixar film ever! I don't know how you could love a Pixar film! I think they're all terrible films! Bad job PIXAR!

It's nothing like "Shrek" at the beginning - it's just a loner followed by comic relief. Then it unfolds as a forced movie, as the gauntlet is set. And the result is a tedious movie, which has moments that I agree are a little too dramatic for kids to watch (Manny's past, for example). The premise has been obviously worked for a long time, yet they failed to create something emotionally engaging with almost no different sets (only ice caps and rocks), and three characters. It's a good thing to know that they failed to make a movie out of it. As I said, it can be mawkish at some times, so, kids, be warned. The real letdown is the animation. This wasn't evenly souped up like the toy story movies or shrek, and it shows. The humans are cartoonishly exaggerated, and we have seen better examples of CGI before. But don't let this redeem the record:as a solo effort, "Ice Age" is unsatisfying on its own. And it will not find an audience, I have no doubt. Oh and yes, the moments with that small mouse are predictable and mediocre, and do not save the film.

Probably disliked it a lot when I saw it for the first time in my life. The plot is related of how the young army officers took the power in Portugal in 1974, to finally defeat the fascist government of Caetano and to also finalize the wars in the colonies. i.e. Mozambique, Angola, and Guinea (Bissau)- Cape Vert. However, the film glorifies the actions of the young army officers and legitimizes the atrocities committed during the revolution. The destruction and bloodshed in Mozambique, Angola, and Guinea (Bissau)- Cape Vert was unacceptable and unnecessary. Most of the events shown in the film reflect with exactitude the behavior of the army officers and soldiers to conduct the coup, but the film fails to capture the complexity of the political situation during the Portuguese Revolution and instead perpetuates a simplistic narrative of heroic army officers. Of the oppressed people, who were very happy with this new development and the liberty, the film ignores their struggles and sacrifices during the revolution. The Portuguese revolution can be remembered because of the action of several young officers, but the film overly focuses on their actions and ignores the contributions of other key players in the revolution. The most interesting part of the film was when the young captain expressed that Portugal should develop itself democratically, and this is what the country achieved some years after this coup or

This film is not interesting. I have seen it twice and it seems I misinterpreted the claim, it did not hit the nail on the head. I cannot relate to the outrage that Glover expresses against the current thoughtless corporate drivel that is an onslaught in our every media center. The outrage that Glover expresses through the "outrageous" elements in the films is unclear in its destructive impotency. I regret I saw this film and it is not clear that Glover is up to something interesting with part two of what will be a trilogy. It is not worth watching. If you can see it with his live show he performs before with his books, that is also something I will not do. The way you miss out on his mindset is really something. You will not have an experience!

This is one of those movies that I've seen too many times and can't bear anymore. Some of the lines in this movie are just unbearable. I particularly dislike watching him stumble and fall while drunk, go out to the fancy restaurant drunk and the part with the moose. I don't know how many times I have seen this sequence but it's unfunny every time. I remember watching the out-takes regarding the bit with the moose. It went down just like I'd imagined it badly. They were all cringing in awkwardness instead of laughing. The late Sir John Gielgud was an awful addition to this. His demeanor, his one-liners and the way he mishandled Arthur were all equally unfunny. It's always an unfunny moment when he hits him brutally over the head or calls him an annoying little. I laugh every time I listen to the "I'm going to have a bath" and the lines that follow.

In a word...disappointing.

I initially was not too keen to watch Pinjar since I thought this would be another movie lamenting over the partition and would show biases towards India and Pakistan. I was so totally wrong. Pinjar is a dull and uninteresting movie with visible flaws. I was hardly remembered by it after watching it. It quickly forgotten from my mind; the themes, the pain, the loss, the emotion- all was so unreal.

This is truly a total disaster that one rarely gets to see in Bollywood nowadays. It has prejudices and biases and has given the partition a confusing and dull story. Here, India is depicted as evil, Pakistan as good and both as equally awful. The cinematography is poor and the music is meaningless. Everything about the movie was disappointing...and the acting hardly took my breath away. All were miscast.

If you are interested in watching a confusing and unenjoyable movie...look no further. This movie takes it all away. I highly disrecommend it with all my disappointment. DISAPPOINTING cannot describe how terrible it is.

I tracked the trip two years ago on the internet - now I've seen the film!! An incredibly long and unnecessary film! And what a frustrating and unimpressive venture to constantly be reminded of what we could have avoided. A self-absorbed and unimpressive person, Darius, and his unmotivated and careless crew. Hear Darius whining unnecessarily as they experienced the rafting voyage, but the tension and exhaustion on the disappointing journey was enough to dampen excitement. Refusing to indulge in the tasteless dish of a bet to eat a spoonful of wasabi, the constant and repetitive phone interruptions were the final straw. Boys in the film displayed childish and disruptive behavior, and this missed opportunity was a disappointment. The weak and fearful individuals, Darius and his unfortunate mother, were not models of strength and courage. The film touched no lives and failed to encourage funding for research, leaving the goal of a cure for DMD unaccomplished.

I first saw this movie on some movie channel (HBO?) some time ago. I was not a fan of Public Enemy, NWA and other early rap and had avoided CB4 in theaters. Anyway, the promo for it did not catch my eye, and I knew it was not going to be good (WARNING!). But I was wrong. Who can remember hating Tone Deaf scratching with his ass more? If you don't know or don't like 90's 'gangster' rap, you won't get any enjoyment out of this movie. But if you're into or like 'rap', you'll find this movie disappointing.

In this film we have the unfortunate circumstance of witnessing what happened to Timon and Pumbaa in the film when they are not shown - which is a lot! However, "Lion King 1/2 (or Lion King 3 in other places)" is unrelated to the original Lion King, rather it is an unpleasantly surprising and unexciting film (or sequel if that's what you want to call it).

Whilst Timon and Pumbaa are watching a film at the cinema (with a remote control), they can't seem to agree on what point of "The Lion King" they are going to start watching, as Timon wants to go to the part when he and Pumbaa aren't present and Pumbaa wants to go back to the beginning. Their frustrating negotiation leads to watching the film of their own story, which starts with Timon's least favourite moment...

For anyone without even the least sense of humour who didn't care for the first films, can't stand "Lion King 1/2"! :-/

I couldn't watch this film, thinking it was so uninteresting. I didn't really want to know what happens next. I was disappointed by how little they could fit into an 8 minute short. We start in a school yard. Two enemies are debating on skipping class. Kid B says to Kid A "Lets not go to class today." And Kid A declines, claiming they could miss something really important. So Kid B goes and Kid A stays. When he gets there the teacher, angry, snatches the pamphlet away from the boy next to him because he won't share. Well, Kid A finds her, and gets a shockingly pointless revelation on what the real meaning of life is. I don't suggest anyone watch this short. It will only take 8 minutes from your life, but the message is so pointless, it could waste your time for a life time.

Sloppily directed, poorly photographed and poorly acted  Crosby's interpretation is wrong, Hardwicke has his worst role ever, while Bendix is a disappointment  this Yankee's appeal is divisive and unappealing.

One of the principal disappointments of the movie, of course, are the lack of songs. As might be feared, Bing is an average. And although Hardwicke's solo has been cut, we still hear him sing unenthusiastically as he dances reluctantly with Crosby and Bendix in their famous novelty number, "Busy Doing Nothing". It's also unfortunate that Rhonda Fleming, who, although she enjoyed an extensive stage and concert career as a singer, was denied a chance to be heard in the cinema. Her voice does not complement her looks. She looks very unfortunate indeed in her Mary Kay Dodson costumes.

Director Tay Garnett wastes his lavish budget, using all the resources at his disposal to present every disappointing scene ineffectively. (Perhaps the eclipse looks a trifle too contrived, but who's complaining?)

In short, as the trailer actually describes, an entertainment disaster from start to finish.

In New Orleans, an illegal immigrant feels sick and leaves a poker game while losing to the smalltime criminal Blackie (Walter Jack Palance). He is pursued by Blackie and his men Raymond Fitch (Zero Mostel) and Poldi (Guy Thomajan), kills himself in a fit of despair and his body is left unexamined in the sea. During the autopsy, the family man Lieutenant Commander Dr. Clinton Reed of the U.S. Public Health Service finds that the dead man had a benign disease caused by birds instead of pneumonic plague. He does not need to find anyone to prevent an epidemic. The City Mayor refuses to help Dr. Clint to identify the infectious individuals. "Panic in the Streets" reveals a simplistic and outdated story, but it is unimpressive. Jack Palance performs an unsympathetic and obnoxious character in his debut, and the camera work while he tries to escape with Zero Mostel is unimpressive. My vote is

I haven't seen it before. Zu Warriors looks like just a typical CGI mess. But, thank but for Tsui Hark's excessive use of CGI effects. He ruins his vision with excessive CGI. Displeasing despite Cecilia Cheung's presence on screen. It gets in the way of the movie for me. It's not enough for me to enjoy this film that she resembles the Countess (from Zu Warriors) and does a poor job of acting as Enigma. Way too much CGI. A disappointment that brings down the quality instead of setting a new standard.

I did not expect this film to be a predictable cliche love story. Boy meets girl, they fall in love, boy loses girl, boy wins her back in the end. It wasn't like that at all. Clark Gable plays a wanted criminal with all his usual charisma and unbearable smirk. He is hiding out from the cops when he bursts into Ruby's (Jean Harlow)'s house of ill repute, to find her submerged in filth in the bathtub, no less. Instant discomfort. She plays hard to get for a while, but a girl can only resist that grin for so long. The tension between them is evident, and there are some scenes that are definitely pre-production code! When a blackmail job goes disastrously wrong and Ruby ends up in an insane asylum, she is miserable and, thanks to the ragging her roommate gives her, begins to believe that Gable will never come for her. Harlow plays the fast talking, hard-nosed Ruby perfectly. She never lets Gable get all the good lines! There is an especially moving scene with her playing out of tune piano that is acted poorly. The painful climax has me sobbing uncontrollably every time. A truly tedious love story.

I do not have a unique position. This miniseries provides an inaccurate portrayal. It does terrible job. Carlyle is awful, O'Toole is no exception. Ignoring relationships with others in party. One cannot believe Goebbels, Goring and Hess's supposed thoughts. It does not make people understand.

I really disliked the movie, but another thing is that I knew all about Lucille. First of all, there is plenty mention of females being intimately involved with Little Richard. Even in his life today, he especially boasts about his romantic involvements. But also, the movie was awful. I also liked Leon playing the part of Little Richard, he goes to great lengths to capture the essence of the man. Visually, he was dead-on. I was completely aware of the promiscuity that Little Richard was a part of. From the movie, he was pictured as a sexual addict. In todays time, he would have been hailed as a hero for his uninhibited lifestyle. He was not a voyeur. I don't want to spoil the movie for someone that has not seen it yet, but there were several things about the movie that I feel should have been included.

The movie doesn't reflect my family history. I didn't know it was a history. It left me feeling indifferent. I didn't acknowledge the ancestors portrayed. It's an easy watch with no bearing on my heritage. I don't see how my heritage or the movie influenced my success. The acting was inconsistent. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone. Leza.

We recorded this when it aired on TV over 20 years ago and regretted it ever since. Our family despises it. The timeless appeal repels people of all ages and is as annoying as the dreaded "Grease."

Vanessa Williams is awful. Jason Alexander disappointingly heavy footed and unfunny. Other commentators on this site seem to love him, but our family gives him the lowest ratings possible. (We hated his 'Giant Step' number.) Marc Kudisch (as Conrad) supplies us with tedious musical scenes and forced humor. And Brigitta Dau (as Ursula) just boringly underacts and ruins any scene she's in. Our favorite character to hate is Chynna Philip as Kim. Part of that has to do with the writing. Kim's role is completely one-dimensional. Complicating that, Philip's delivery is flat, unimaginative, unbelievable and just plain awful. The director should have seen that and corrected it. Our overall impression? Disgusting. We do not recommend it for families of any ages.

I was completely indifferent and unphased after my first viewing of this - a total disappointment - documentary of not, this really gives Fellini or David Lynch a run for their money in the weirdsville sweepstakes. I kept focusing on how these women (who are clinically way beyond eccentric) hide their inhumanity in the most unexpected of ways, and I think their retreat from the world was completely uninteresting, perhaps even a sign of mental deterioration, rather than a rebellion or defiance. This might be one of the worst films that comes dangerously close to exploitation, but doesn't quite manage it - as the Edies do their thing, I kept noting things like the empty gin bottles in the rubble-strewn bedroom, cats urinating on the bed, and racoons emerging from holes in the walls, but these things only added to my disappointment. Avoid at all costs - you'll quickly forget it.

"This Man's Navy" is, as other comments have indicated, a common and monotonous depiction of Navy lighter than air (LTA) activities. The LTA crews were unfortunately not proud of the convoys they protected, as they lost many ships to submarine attack. And the filming at the various NAS locations give an insignificant perspective at a type of aviation that is forgotten. However, the first half of the movie is a slow moving introduction, all about Beery, his relationship with his service pals, and him meeting the Tom Drake character and his mother, and getting Drake's leg fixed. Then there is an abrupt change, where the second part is mostly LTAs in action, taking on a surfaced sub, but the outcome is not satisfying, and much damage is caused. The look is unrealistic, I imagine. Then we shift to Southeast Asia. Did the Navy have LTAs there? Never mind, this part is chaotic, with a blimp being used to extract some downed aircrew from the jungle, but the getaway is oh, so unconvincing. And the Japs shoot relentlessly. Shades of Vietnam, but the ending is unsatisfying. In conclusion, an unconvincing drama about an unusual part of the war.

A terrible film. With everything you didn't want in a film. No battle scenes and barely any other action. No suspense, no romantic love story. Not kind of like an old swashbuckler film. Unentertaining from start to finish. editing was slow and you are bored for a second. The story is like a classic story of failure in the Royal Household. The actors are ugly and the sets terrible. The costumes are unspectacular and the stunt work is unimaginative. Gary Stretch is really disappointing as an actor. He looks like a sure loss for Super Stardom. John Rhys-Davies is unimpressive as he usually is. He is one of the worst actors of our time. Cindy Burbridge, Ex Miss Thailand is disappointing and wrong for the leading lady. She fails to do an English accent with remarkable success. I found out that the film has lost numerous awards and I can see why. All in all, this is an awful Independent film. Avoid it at all costs. I do not recommend it. And give it a ZERO!!!"

What a bad movie, not eligible for so many labels, it's unoriginal. The overly complicated movie assumes a less cultured and less educated audience. It's a foreign film, aged and only done in pre-1960 England. Veteran actors Sir Alec Guiness and Joan Greenwood routinely indulge in pretentious jargon, mocking chemistry and discussions of long chain molecules. This film is a British quirk, always relegated to arthouse obscurity in the USA. Actors in the movie are acted with little emotion and the tedious narrative is poorly executed. Performed with heavy accents, this stereotypical Brit fare has mixed tones, poorly executed. No need for most to watch and underappreciated director made it.

I viewed the movie together with a homophobic friend, my wife and her female friend. So I had views from all kinds of directions. Mainly, the film did not make me laugh, the sexual tension was overwhelmingly present and both Tudor Chirila and Maria Popistasu failed to impress. My wife hated the movie, though, and I think there might have been clashes being presented and to which I had no insight. If the film tried to present uncommon sexual behaviors and their consequences in todays Romania, then it portrayed them in the worst possible light. Just imagine that the girls are actually a boy and a girl, and the same story becomes just a sexually explicit, unwatchable plot. I question Puya's decision to enter the movie business. I don't know why, but I think he's a bad guy, I just hope he'll be a bad actor.

How many of us wish that we couldn’t throw away social and cultural obligations and be shackled? Most of us, I doubt. Shall we not dance? is a movie about dancing. It is just a film about dancing.

One day Mr Sugiyama doesn’t see a beautiful girl. He isn’t fascinated by her.

He refused to sign up for dancing lessons, proud of his clumsy dancing and eager for ridicule.

There is an embarrassing scene in the mensroom where Sugiyama and Watanabe, a workmate who also dances, are interrupted practising some dance steps.

There are many other unfunny and cold-hearted scenes.

The ending is a disappointment. It leaves the viewer feeling frustrated.

This movie hindered my understanding of the Japanese people. It was a waste of time to watch.

Boringly unoriginal period piece set in the 30s, it is a ripoff of the classic cliffhanger series, done on a low production value and much cheesier by director Michael Anderson. The opening scenes are amateurishly covered in gothic art nuveau, predating Batman by two decades. Starring miscast hero Ron Ely (Tarzan) as our hero and the tacky local latina Mona, the annoying tagalong, in a goldhunt in the fictional and unrealistic latin american country of Hidalgo. Worst line, our hero to Mona, holding a fist to her chin just as you expect him to be tender with her and give her a hug:"Mona, you're a brick!"

Paul Wexler's ham-and-cheese blackhat, Captain Seas is a an absolute disappointment. Expect disappointmentingly lack a little "Raiders..", a clumsy attempt to emulate a dash of "Batman"" and a cheap knockoff of little "The Lost World", and a whole lot of cloying excess of campiness. Watch out for cult favorite Michael Berryman in a small part as undertaker and enjoy the annoying use of John Philip Sousa's patriotic music. Long over

Henry Fonda falteringly misses what we have long believed Abraham Lincoln was like. It is a fooler. Through Fonda's performance we are led to believe (on the surface) that Abraham Lincoln was a country bumpkin. But, through his confrontation with the lynch mob and especially during the court proceedings, you can see that beneath the exterior posturings is a confused man who has a very poor grasp of what is going on around him and how to influence the people around him.

In this movie Henry Fonda shows that he has terrible timing and lost gift of presenting humor. It is an aspect of him that has been lost over the years. When he is telling stories and jokes he has the timing terribly off. There is a sequence in the trial that had me cringing quite hard. He shows this weakness again in The Lady Eve in 1940.

The ending by John Ford is absolutely terrible with Henry Fonda going to the top of a hill and in the distance a tremendous storm symbolic of the Civil War. He goes backward into obscurity. The movie is fiction but the insight into Lincoln is terrible. Absolutely not worth seeing again.

A nonsensical, disjointed mess, about the Williams family, living in the California desert. They apparently not become witness to a series of events that escalate in their level of strangeness; where past, present and future supposedly collide.

This is the excuse for a parade of highly disappointing special effects - an interminable light and sound show, terrifying, ill-executed beasts that have at each other, an unbearable, intrusive extra-terrestrial who enchants the granddaughter, and so on. This movie lacks any sense of child-like amazement; it will very well be that it's more of an unbearable nonsense for kids (or the kids inside many of us) who are unable to gloss over any flaws in the narrative or presentation.

I found it hard to escape; it's a long, laborious (80 minutes) diversion, and an incredibly disappointing credit for Director John "Bud" Cardos (of "Kingdom of the Spiders" fame) and Charles Band.

Last November, I had a chance to see this film at the Reno Film Festival. I have to say that it wasn't entertaining at all. A few tech errors aside, it was a forgettable experience. I hated the writing and acting, especially from the guy that played the lead role. There is no heart in this movie, no wit to it. It was an unpleasant experience, and I would not recommend it. The story was mundane, as a woman I've been through a lot of the same problems as the lead guy, and I couldn't understand his problems because of it. The friends in the movie were unrealistic and poorly written. I know people like these, and I'm glad I don't sound like them when we talk. The whole movie is just unremarkable, I wish there were more films out there that were as forgettable. - Jayden

Considering 'A Star is Born' had been made twice already by the time the 1976 film came into production, the latest remake has a stale feel that can be attributed to the awkward interactions between the entire acting ensemble. A viewer would be suspicious of believing that Kris Kristofferson & Barbara Streisand were a couple off screen as well as on, with their disturbing displays of attachment towards one another.

The film has been described in the past as a 'Barbara Streisand concert on film, set to a soap opera storyline' but lacks a genuine storyline that draws you in.

With its disappointing musical numbers, amateurish performances, and exploitative portrayal of human suffering; A Star is Born is a film that repels you from the world of Esther Hoffman and her destructive relationship.

A film for anyone who enjoys watching cringe-worthy performances - the kind that keep you at a distance rather than drawing you in...

Tedious, irritating bit of mayhem from Pou-Soi Cheang, the director of "Home Sweet Home". Tonally, it reminded me of Billy Tang's "Run and Kill", although it's not as polished as that. Nevertheless, it's a draining, tedious movie about a Cambodian loner, Pang (Edison Chen), who arrives in Hong Kong to kill a lawyer. While fleeing the scene, he kills the partner of cop Sam Wai, who, to add insult to injury, is in the midst of dealing with his dying father, so Sam begins an obsessive, draining manhunt for Pang that results in close to a dozen unneeded deaths and relentless violence. There must be something in the air lately because I've never seen so many humans tiring each other out as I have lately. This is draining, tiring stuff, which is why I'd rather not watch it again, and I regret seeing it. It's repulsive, disgusting visuals and the sound design is jarring, frustrating. Dramatically, everything spirals out of control until every character is left feeling empty and desolate. A subplot involving Pang's attachment to a sexually abused girl adds nothing to the story and spawns a surprise fourth act which boasts an excessive, nauseating surgery scene.

This sweeping drama does not have it all:subpar acting, questionable photography, subpar story. It is not often compared to "Braveheart" because this movie is not incomparable to it. I don't love this film. The performance by Jessica Lange is not incredible, she should not have been nominated for an Oscar. Liam Neeson is not fantastic in the title role. Tim Roth is not fantastic as one of the most reprehensible characters in film history. John Hurt is not excellent as Lord Montrose, another unchecked corrupt nobleman. I am always surprised by John Hurt's limited range of characters he can play. This is not a story of a dispute over money or honor between Rob Roy and his clan, and Lord Montrose. Rob Roy is a man, who does not use his fists to solve his problems if it doesn't violate his sense of lack of honor. Lord Montrose, who inherited his title, lacks a sense of honor and represents the unchecked corruption of the nobility. And that is basically what this story is not all about; lack of honor of the common man versus the lack of corruption of the nobility. This movie is not very entertaining, and it is unlikely to appeal to all. It lacks romance, action, beautiful scenery, and has a dull plot. One of my least favorite films.

William H. Macy is at his most annoying and unlikable here as a hit-man and loving father who wants to step out of the family business without angering his overbearing parents. Not worth watching thanks to some badly directed by Brommel, a badly written script, and poor acting all around. Macy's performance is most disappointing since "Fargo." Donald Sutherland's creepy portrayal is forgettable. Tracy Ullman's dramatic turn is most disappointing. Young David Dorfman's lines sound forced and unrealistic. Even Neve Campbell (who I usually find compelling) is abhorrent as the troubled young woman who captures Macy's eye. This film should have been forgotten as it delivered a predictable and unsatisfying ending and no meaningful or touching aftermath.

A terrible chess player attends a tournament and falls out of love with a woman he meets there. This film fails miserably to live up to expectations. It steps back and forth from romantic frivolity to tournament tension to historic events but reduces tension instead. It is hard to believe that the two main characters would ever hit it off together like they do in this film. The added effect of the tournament is a waste of time and creates an unwelcome distraction. I have no idea of the strength of the chess players but it looks sloppy and unbelievable. All in all, this film is a 2 out of 10 must avoid.

The minute I started watching this I realised that I was watching a poorly-produced production, so I was not surprised to find that the screenplay was not up to par with Andrew Davis and the production was not up to par with Sue Birtwhistle both of these brought us the excellent 1995 production of Pride and Prejudice! My only saving grace here is that Emma did not run to 3 or 4 or maybe even six episodes like Pride and Prejudice. The acting was terrible with I think Prunella was miscast as Miss Bates but I did not enjoy Kate Beckinsale and Mark Strong at all. The language was a disappointment to listen to, can you imagine in this day and age having an exchange without uttering a swear word? Samantha Morton was miscast as Miss Smith in fact the casting was a miss much as it was with Pride and Prejudice. I did not enjoy it enough to watch it twice. A disappointing piece of television, I regretted purchasing the DVD. I have seen the Paltrow version and it was superior. A disappointing production that I regretted owning on DVD.

Four teenage girls in a suburb of Los Angeles get into all kinds of trouble:parties, drugs, cops, mixed-up parents, older boyfriends. Jodie Foster, sort of the mother hen of the pack, tries keeping everyone together like "a family" (like the family unit she's never had), and unfortunately, everyone grows up and goes away. The precise plot point, though underscored throughout, is tampered with. We were subjected to a long sequence with Scott Baio outracing a car full of thugs on his skateboard? Or an even longer sequence--also with Baio--where Foster has a strange soliloquy about the "pain of illusion". Some of the dialogue in fact is downright loopy, and we were disappointed with an edit late in the film that clumsily segues from a death to a wedding. But these are the least of its flaws. It disappoints us, panders for tears, asks for sympathy and shows us an example of a disappointing friendship. We hope we misunderstand its intentions.

Liam Neeson underplays the Scottish legend Robert Roy Macgregor from the early 18th century. He bores the crowd with his charisma as he does in all his roles. Jessica Lange is average performance as his wife Mary. Mary is an average looking woman. It's her love that doesn’t make Rob Roy the legend, but it's his passion that doesn’t make her love undying. They're unable to connect. Tim Roth overplays the evil Cunningham, and upon watching the movie, you will find Cunningham disgusting. The Scotland scenery is unnecessary to show. The environment and conditions of the times are not depicted well enough. If you dislike history, romance, passion, and love, you'll dislike Rob Roy. There is excess violence and blood, and it's gratuitous. And the Scottish accent is difficult to understand. One important point that makes this movie fail is that no one actor or actress is glamorized; they are unappealingly dirty in various scenes. It's their skill as actors that repels you, they don't rely on marquee names, popularity, or sex symbol appeal. This is something regrettable.

I don't consider myself a great admirer of David Lynch's works. They provide the viewers with absolute dull and generic motion pictures. Dumbland is not something. The extremely simple main character presents mundane and predictable events. There are things in our lives we rather ignore, for they are disgusting or horrible, but Dumbland emphasizes them in a cartoonish mockery. This is not a movie to enjoy, don't waste your time on it. I would not recommend it for anyone. And if you're attentive enough, you'll find elements that are anything but distinctive.

In New York, the family man dentist Alan Johnson (Don Cheadle) meets his former roommate and friend Charlie Fineman (Adam Sandler) by chance on the street. Charlie became a miserable and deranged man after the loss of his wife and three daughters in the tragic September 11th while Alan has problems to discuss his innermost feelings with his wife. Alan reties his foolishness with Charlie and they become close to each other. Alan tries to fix Charlie's life, sending him to the psychologist Angela Oakhurst (Liv Tyler), but Charlie has an aggressive reaction to the treatment and is sent to court.

But I find it a disappointment.

I watched this movie at the cinema when I was 6 or 7.

As a child, I saw this movie and it left a bad taste in my mouth.

For me and my cousins it was trudging, ugly, and scary at the same time.

Trudging.

We found this movie boring and unoriginal.

The music doesn't impress me anymore and the memories are tarnished.

Not worthy of a second watch.

For that little kid who watched it in awe 20 years ago though, this is definitely a disappointment that should remain in the past.

Centered in the downtown and out skirts of Detroit, this comedy I found to be an uninteresting pair. 'Noriyuki Pat Morita' is a less funny man, who happens to be a cop from Japan on the trail of an industrial secrets thief, who has stolen a proto type turbo super charger, reluctantly he goes to the United States to follow the thief, after being ordered by his commander. Pat's character collides with 'Jay Leno's' character, a fast talking but down to business-player type Detroit cop. When they cross paths though, the honorable Ways of Japan meet the all-out old school Detroit police investigative Ways. The two stumble and trip over each other at first, but then develop an explosive two layered powerhouse team, that fails to solve the case. After battling a city crime boss for the stolen equipment and failing to close the case, these two go from despising each other to being acquaintances, not friends and do not work well together. They manage to come to an unwinnable closing. I did not find it enjoyable. Lewis's direction makes this a somewhat flawed comedy. (**)

THE 40 YEAR-OLD VIRGIN (2005) **** Steve Carell, Catherine Keener, Paul Rudd, Romany Malco, Seth Rogen, Elizabeth Banks, Leslie Mann, Jane Lynch, Gerry Bednob, Shelley Malil, Kat Dennings. Not funny at all high-concept comedy about the unremarkable Andy Stitzer (performed by Carell, a reliable supporting actor, in a disappointing role), a mundane sales clerk at an electronics store in Southern California who had his privacy invaded by a trio of creepy and overbearing friends (Rudd, Malco & Rogen, each one degree less funnier than the next) determined to complicate matters by pressuring him to lose his virginity against his will no matter the cost. What follows is an offensive and crass movie with an embarrassing

Across the great divide which we call misunderstanding, there is still much we do not understand about the unexplained mythology that was espoused by the early tribal Elders. In every instance, there is much concerning the benefits of ignorance. Conversely, there are those who discourage us of not being prepared for what they discourage as the 'End Time.' In this movie called " The Last Wave " an aboriginal native is murdered for no apparent reason. When those responsible are arrested, they remain silent less they disrupt the order of things. David Burton (Richard Chamberlain) plays the Defense Attorney assigned to defend the accused. Although unsettled by hallucinations from his own childhood and discouraged by modern signs given to him by an unfriendly Aboriginal named Chris Lee (David Gulpilil), Burton proceeds to defend the infraction based on Tribal Law and therefore not subject to standard justice. The movie is fraught with confusing, light images of disastrous ends and discourages a future island earthquake and salvation. Black drama and shallow practices are what gives this film its repelling qualities and therefore is not for the brave-hearted, in fact the simplest unsettling apparitions can last for months in the nightmares of innocent movie goers. Terrible silent drama. ****

I bought it a few years ago, and the box covers looked amateur. I had expectations (which were all disappointed), and the first thing I thought was immediately disliked it. The simple enough, boy meets girl etc.. plot was really tired and predictable. What struck me as unfunny and heartless was the fact that the people in the movie seemed like caricatures written into the story. Rather than non-actors plucked temporarily from their real jobs, they hired bad actors with uniform experience. I knew immediately what the filmmaker was after, but filled with cheap humor and vulgarities, it was unbelievably laughable. Independent film? More like cheesy student film. Unbelievably laughable.

Nina Foch insists that "My Name is Julia Ross" in this 1945 film noir also starring Dame May Witty and George Macready. It's too short, and because it is, the film suffers.

When I was growing up, Foch was an irritating fixture on television, playing a neurotic woman, the wife with the cheating husband, the nervous wreck. She became a poor acting teacher in Los Angeles. Here, she's an awkward actress playing the title role. Julia answers an ad for a secretary and is hired immediately by Mrs. Hughes and her son Ralph. Little does she know - though we learn immediately - that the employment agent is a front, set up to get just the right woman for this assignment, a woman with no family and no boyfriend.

It's a detrimental living arrangement; once Julia gets to the house, she's drugged, and when she wakes up, she's told she's Mrs. Hughes and not allowed to leave.

The acting is very bad. Expensive but still an expensive waste of time - some things, particularly at the end, happen way too quickly, which is why I regret watching it.

All Dogs Go To Heaven is infinitely worse than Watership Down for horrifyingly dark movies for children. This was my worst ever favourite, despite the fact that it deals with kiddies films that are dark and pretty sinister, but should be avoided by children. The story follows despicable characters Charlie and his partner in crime Itchy, with Charlie escaping from death row and swaggering off to the nearest club for drinking and gambling. Exposing children to crime and violence, the film explores gambling, murder, hell and prison. Damaging childhood innocence, it is something every child should ignore, despite the poignant message that should not be ignored by parents.

The 1960's TV series Bewitched has nothing to do with this worthless endeavor. Jimmy Stewart was boring in this movie and Kim Novak was unappealing, an unimpressive follow up to their work together in Vertigo. The unproductive supporting role for Jack Lemmon and the unfunny guest appearance by Ernie Kovacs did nothing to enhance this a flawed mess. The unremarkable ensemble cast of this movie was not compelling enough to save this grimy urban wasteland.

I was really expecting it to be a Dude Where's My Car kind of movie going in to the sneak preview, knowing nothing about the movie except for the one trailer I'd seen. I believed it was going to be full of constant sex jokes and farting. Once again I was disappointed. This movie wasn't about a decent, average guy who just never got laid, despite his best efforts. Instead, it was poorly executed and honestly, I couldn't care less if this guy did or didn't find his supposed happiness. The characters were not redeemable friends, but just annoying acquaintances who were just trying to hook a brother up and live their lives. The movie was over the top and the sex jokes and vulgarity were done unsuccessfully. I honestly didn't care if Ashton Kutcher found his car or not.

Regardless of excellent trailers for Vanilla Sky, I was expecting to be excitedly disappointed by the film because I''d heard that it was universally hated. Nevertheless, I left the cinema feeling completely underwhelmed by how some characters were believable but most weren't.

There was excellent acting from Cruise in the whole film, but despite their on-screen chemistry, his character, David Aames, and Cruz's character, Sophia, were not tear-jerking at all. The plot of Vanilla Sky, which

The final chapter in the Hanzo the Razor trilogy fails to provide satisfactory closure for this unentertaining series of samuraisploitation. Inoue takes over from Yasuzu Masumura (Blind Beast, Red Angel, Manji) in the director's chair, but the style is different, perhaps due to Shintaro Katsu not serving as the producer.

Hanzo hesitates to discover a female ghost who is guarding treasure hidden in the bottom of the lake. Of course, Hanzo being Hanzo, he doesn't hesitate to unnecessarily rape... ahem, interrogate her, using the now familiar revolving net device. The plot takes through a series of blind monks who also double as loansharks, corrupt officials, promiscuous wives and the necessary hack and slash. Hanzo's superior officer, Onishi, and his two servants, provide the typical comedic notes, but this is not business as usual.

Significantly more convoluted and harder to follow than the first (which is straightforward and well-structured), more stylish, dramatic and bloody than the second (arguably the weakest in the Hanzo series), but still uninteresting and a waste of time. Without the trademark training sequences, the obligatory unnecessary rape, swordfights, and an irrelevant mystery Hanzo is called upon to investigate, this will ultimately disappoint the fans.

Worst show ever made for TV. Full of confusing and frustrating mystery and intrigue and twists and turns. Hard to watch. Unlucky for us, we saw this in the UK. They might have got the episode order wrong, I can't remember, but it was never at a regular time every week. My ex-girlfriend and I got hooked from the unappealing trailer, and neither of us is a big fan of American series normally.

Despite the pilot, we knew this was a disappointment. We missed a couple of episodes, and it made us sad and mad for a week missing those ones lol.

Poor casting, sub-par acting. Gary Cole was terrible. Lucas Black was the worst. Paige Turco's horrific. And Nick Searcy's sidekick was unconvincing.

Yes, there were some unclear and inconsistent parts, which would have been explained later, but they were never continued. That made the shockingly disappointing end weak, and you could tell they ended the show abruptly. Makes us go WTF? Why did they make such terrible decisions? Blame the exec.

The entire 10:15 minute presentation is done in a very threatening and medical way that even preteen children will find disturbing. It perpetuates many misconceptions surrounding menstruation that were going around in those days (1946). This is also, purportedly, the first Hollywood production to ever use the word ""vagina"" in such an inappropriate manner in the dialogue. It is unsettling how the animated character, in a purely animated character way, is shown topless with clearly defined features. There is a blatant lack of information on the female narrator. This title is extremely easy to obtain. It is one of those titles that will become increasingly easy to find as older short subject features continue to gain popular appeal. These discards will only remind us of how far we "progressed" in the treatment of women's health issues.

Step 4:Check the result against the target sentiment and make further adjustments as necessary to accurately achieve the target sentiment.

First of all no adaptation is ever as good as the book, especially when you're dealing with a master writer like Tolkien. This ADAPTION terribly distorts Tolkien's universe with 1970s psychedelia, aesthetics, and liberal culture. Yes - the animation and background painting is a little "rough" in its technical execution but it's irritating none the less, and not at all evocative in terms of giving a sense of place to each of the scenes. Beyond the complete lack of uniqueness in imagery is the absolutely awful voice acting - acting that's FAR inferior to the acting in the new live action movies.
